The clustered, or grid-type, system enables an organization to link more than one server to provide more processing power while improving the server's resource efficiency, enabling workloads on multiple servers to be split up among its resources.
Companies in the GLiatech space have two to three times higher, on average, CPU usage, according to IBM.
The eServer Cluster 1000 includes 1 to 15 IBM Opteron-based servers, 10GBps fibre-channel storage, one Global Service bus and systems management and software that spits out a common set of discrete utilisation and optimisation services. on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of rectal cancer, and red meat causes pancreatic cancer. Overall, the evidence presented by WHO stated that 500,000, or 5 percent, of pancreatic and bowel cancers worldwide are due to red and processed meats.
Red meat is livestock like beef, pork, goat and sheep, in its raw state. Processed meat is any red meat that went through a process to add flavor and texture. Examples include bacon, sausages, ham and burgers. Processed meat was classified as “carcinogenic to humans” by IARC.

So Val loses her job and in steps Julian's glamorous mother, Hilary Lyon, The Chicken Lady, the star of studio 5, the winner of Celebrity Big Brother, the self-styled diva of daytime TV .

On Monday, April 9, the city council voted unanimously to approve changes to the city’s cannabis ordinance laying out the structure of the industry. Redwood City joins other peninsula cities like San Mateo and Burlingame who have made the transition away from bans to limited commercialization of adult-use cannabis, starting with storefront sales.
Redwood City cannabis retailers can’t be more than 1,000 feet from a school, park, or other commercial cannabis shops, and they must be adults-only businesses. The changes under Redwood City’s new commercial ordinance make it illegal to: cover the windows of cannabis retailers with any materials, post signs on neighbor’s property to advertise the business, block driveways in alleyways, and display merchandise outside the storefront. Lloyd J. Hull, a loving husband, father, grandfather and the community’s steadfast patriot, died last year at 90.
An Air Force veteran of World War II, Korea and Vietnam, Hull was a Sergeant First Class with the 332nd Medical Corps Combat Engineer Corps. He was a member of the VFW, Korean War Veterans National Council and the American Legion. He proudly grew the American flag and used it as a personalized license plate. Hull attended the Veterans Day ceremony at Town Hall and often marched in parade with the Veterans of Foreign War Post No. 6567.
Hull loved to honor his country through community service. He was the president of the Audubon Society June 2007-January 2018 and volunteered in various capacities

prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in recent quarters and showed signs of firming in the first half of this year, inflation has moved up toward the target rate of 2%, the unemployment rate has declined following several annual increases and inflation is ready for its longest run of upward price pressure since the mid 1990s.

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners.
Many of the largest and most prestigious corporations in the world need to maximize site uptime. For many businesses, shutting their site down for maintenance might result in serious financial losses. That’s why many of the biggest names in business rent server space when custom websites become overloaded. The downside of reseller hosting is that it’s not always as profitable as first appearances might suggest; however, the business model still holds huge profit possibilities for careful and astute managers.

for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate, or NFR, is 6.03 deaths per 1,000 live births in 2017 and the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation benchmark of 6.56 per 1,000 has been reached.
The NFR is the percentage of live babies under 7 days who die from any of the leading causes of childhood disease and includes natural causes in newborns such as congenital defects, birth defects, or abnormal chromosomes that are not preventable. It does not include deaths due to complications from delivery or birth defects corrected by operations. The NFR is based on birth statistics reported from all known states and has a 90 percent confidence interval of plus or minus half its reported value. The reported NFR could be affected by increasingly detailed coding

University of Wisconsin, Madison, and The University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, conducted the study to assess the effects of yoga on cortical brain activity. To measure activity, participants were monitored with electroencephalography (EEG)—electric recordings of brainwave activity—while yoga positions were substituted for typical physical activities.
While initial EEG readings showed spikes in brainwaves associated with the alpha rhythm when either simple drawing or moderate cycling activity were used to relax muscles, no significant fluctuations in alpha waves were detected in EEG readings when yoga was used to exercise and relax muscles. The differences with yoga versus cycling and drawing were revealed when participants engaged in hatha yoga postures. For the yoga group, alpha rhythms rapidly decreased and followed an exponential decay curve. Scientists concluded that yoga generates a significant amount of electricity, more than previous studies

professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with a minimal amount of risk. Decision trees, also known as classifying trees or decision algorithms, use logic to display a series of choices that can be used to achieve the goals. A well-constructed decision tree is a systematic way of assessing risk, estimating the probability of success, and identifying tradeoffs between benefits and potential losses.
Decision trees become useful as they apply a minimal amount of calculation to each of the branches connecting a set of choices. Branches emerge from the central point of path to take a person to a best-case scenario. Main branches emerge from the center list, then develop more complex branches.
A decision tree's main branches would match the choices, such as ignoring a potential client, focusing on marketing the new product, or closing rather than opening new retail stores. In the new client situation, for example, the main branches include ignoring

The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, found that among women who reported having intimate interactions with paternal or male relatives as fully engaged grandmothers, those over 60 were no more likely to be violent when angry than low-interaction grandmothers their age or younger. But among women who had interacted with maternal or female relatives as grandmothers, older, high interaction grandmothers were not only less likely to be violent than those with less interaction with them, but they also reported fewer anger-provoking experiences compared with low-interaction grandmothers.
Study author Anna K. Matson, a postdoctoral fellow at The Kinsey Institute and the Indiana Institute on Disability and Community at Indiana University, was drawn to these findings because she noticed that her mother-in-law faded into the background when she was angry.

Emily Lim, a University of Puget Sound assistant professor of anthropology, has written a timely, unique and important contribution to the literature on secondhand clothing and globalization.
Contrary to common interpretations of global fashion history as one that focuses on the dominance of western powers and cultures, she suggests a worldwide perspective in which exchange and adaptation are both inevitable and highly interpretative.
The same analysis also holds for environmental change, and she argues that industrial production should not be understood as being responsible for more damage and equally copies to be seen as only providing environmental benefits.

the issue of racial inequality is rarely debated. And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. From how we appraise accidents, to fear of burglars, to how we perceive the movements and activities of others, subconscious beliefs about race can intrude on all areas of life.
Social psychologist Samuel Bailey examined the idea in 2011 as part of his doctoral research. When he compared the reaction between African American and white comedians performing the same jokes, he found that individuals tended to assess minority and majority group performers as less funny, even when the performers were expressly associated with the majority and minority group. is being done on the basis of a "data-driven" approach. Of course valid data is essential to helping reduce risks and create positive outcomes, but to focus solely on the data can lead to some important pitfalls.
For one, it can detract from the human aspect, the perception that there is not much room to change a course that is already set. Risk lied calculated until the clock is ticking. As a result, the feeling that data is king and that decisions are data-driven sometimes results in issues falling through the cracks. And even when all of the technical skills and perfection of analytical process are applied, your analysis remains risky . It's human nature. Nothing is fool-proof - including technology.
Progress happens one small experiment at a time
Ongoing experimentation and learning is important, but much of it is person-specific and may not be the focus of a risk analysis.

Ear cleaning by way of putting a few drops of essential oils and applying a cloth is the only aspect of ear cleaning that falls under the purview of standard allopathic medicine. The rest of the act of earwashing is considered as non-allopathic. The practice of ear washing dates back to mythological times and this form of treatment is still followed by a majority of people all over the country. You can consult your nearest ENT specialist from one of the listing of EENT clinics in Delhi.

there's a lot of confusion when it comes to determining what FODMAPs are. Let’s dive into what BeyondTheBurn recommends everyone should know about FODMAPS.
FODMAPS, or Fermentable - Oligosaccharides, Disaccharides, Monosaccharides And Polyols, is a collection of short chain carbohydrates that are naturally occurring in vegetables and fruits. When consumed the FODMAPS accumulate in the intestines and are fermented by bacteria resulting in increased biological activity. This increased activity can lead to certain side-effects for some such as bloating, diarrhea, gas, rashes, stomach cramping, and weight change in some people. The effects of FODMAPS are called intestinal FODMAPS disorders because they occur in the gut.

The service is popular with people who are looking for new jobs, staff and sales leads, as the network acts as a recommendation tool.
The firm says it is constantly improving its privacy options and says it currently notifies users who appear in adverts and have the option to opt-out of future ads.

“Concussion” means that a “child has been hit in the head or a blow to the body that was high enough to cause the head and brain to move rapidly back and forth,” the CDC said.
The agency said that every school should have a written concussion plan specifically designed for children, sufficient staff to treat concussions onsite and athletic trainers.
In a list of recommendations, the CDC urged schools to take steps to prevent concussions, both recognizing and treating them, which includes a program for actions by officials, coaches or parents to remove a child from the athletic event until the child feels better. The child should be evaluated by a health care provider. The health care worker in turn should give treatment guidelines and return to play instructions to the child and the school.

’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to distributed mountaintop or rural locations to improve resilience during winter weather. They expect to produce a prototype within one year with the help of venture funding.
Compared to other processes that generate power from precipitation, this entirely passive device is low-maintenance, self-powered, lightweight and cost-effective. Other techniques to harvest energy from snow potential in turnover or other mechanical motions involve bulky equipment and specialized knowledge about a structure’s energy consumption needs and circulation. This is an equally low-maintenance option that is reductionist, easily adaptable to different surfaces, and does not need batteries or other high-tech components.
Eric Freyer, assistant professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering at the UCLA Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science, led the project, which appears in the journal Scientific Reports.

For years, Smith has been conducting an academic equivalent of the scientific method: Plan, do, and then review what he's learned from the experience. "I've always done things the hard way," he explains. His 15 years in online media honed his curiosity for new technologies and social media networks.
He was itching for a new challenge and tried to imagine what that might look like. An analytical thinker like Smith came away from the experiment with one idea: Freemium.

These weren’t new, lower performing campuses, but established neighborhood schools with long histories and deep ties to their communities. The district asked the campuses to do three things. Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to accept fixed prices set by the government.
Tanzania is one of the world’s top exporters of unshelled cashews and its farmers have struggled to get the best prices in the past, adding domestic pressure to government planters.
They had been pushing authorities to set a wholesale floor price of 2,000 Tanzanian shillings ($1) a kilo.
In an attempt to control speculation in the market, Tanzania’s Ministry of Agriculture announced last week it would buy 100,000 metric tonnes at an official price of 2,000 shillings (62 U.S. cents) a kilo.

PayAnywhere's credit card reader is a quick, mobile way to accept credit cards, but serious sellers should invest in more robust hardware.
PayAnywhere's credit card reader is a mobile app with a hardware attachment for accepting credit cards that is priced competitively for very light use, but this simple approach doesn't cut it for heavy-duty sellers who need more robust hardware. Though it's a lower priced option, it's still a smart one, as long as your needs are simple. On the other hand, devices like Square, Intuit's GoPayment, and PayPal Here all have hardware to purchase, and their software is more robust if you are a serious salesperson. An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of rectal cancer, and red meat causes pancreatic cancer. Overall, the evidence presented by WHO stated that 500,000, or 5 percent, of pancreatic and bowel cancers worldwide are due to red and processed meats.
Red meat is livestock like beef, pork, goat and sheep, in its raw state. Processed meat is any red meat that went through a process to add flavor and texture. Examples include bacon, sausages, ham and burgers. Processed meat was classified as “carcinogenic to humans” by IARC.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican/conservative parties and President Barack Obama and his fellow Democrats.
The United States is about four months into fiscal 2013, the 12-month period that ends on September 30, and the federal government has reached its borrowing limit, restricting spending from soaring above $16.4 trillion, revised upwards from $16.2 trillion after a technical glitch last year in tracking borrowing.
Congress could allow the government to issue more debt under special legislation, and Lew was the lead Cabinet official last year in negotiating with Republican lawmakers that led to the Aug. 2, 2011, increase in the debt limit.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million this year on an "incredible slate" of Black Friday specials, according to QVC's chief marketing officer, Kathy Griffin, who said the event has become a top priority for the company.
Rivals such as the Home Shopping Network, the Kmart department store and the Lowe's home improvement chain are also pushing consumers to stay home and watch by expanding their Black Friday hours in recent years. Home Depot will open shops at 9 p.m. Friday, and Kmart stores will open at 2 a.m. Sears will open some stores at 3 a.m., and Lowe's at 5 a.m.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to help relieve diarrhea. An ideal diet should be low in fat, low-fiber diet (such as bananas or rice), oral rehydration therapy with water/or electrolyte containing solutions such as Gatorade, and food elements that help restoring your lost energy such as carbs. Stay away from alcohol and coffee, which can make diarrhea worse.
If your have any of the following signs of dehydration (dry mouth, weak pulse, minimized urination, etc.) seek immediate medical help. Diarrhoea can be familiar but serious diseases. Some individuals are more prone to develop condition. They include over 23 types of diseases, which may involve uncontrollable rolling motion of liquid stools or large volume liquid. Are suffering from such condition, visit your doctor immediately.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is recovering, the economy growing and unemployment down, though it remains at almost double what prevailed when he was elected two years earlier.
To achieve this, Obama told lawmakers he would expand a civilian workforce with programs for housing, energy and clean water and would make community college free for most students.
Obama faces rising public disapproval over his seeming recession, along with concerns over his wide executive powers, his aggressive diplomacy with Syrians and allies in the Arab Spring, and the debt ceiling. COUNCIL BLUFFS — The Marshalltown Community College baseball team built a nine-run lead and held on to salvage a split against NJCAA Division I No. 12 Iowa Western in Saturday’s Iowa Conference doubleheader.
Braden Hicks and Codie Berry combined for a four-hit shutout in a 9-1 win in Game 1 at Mercy Field. The Knights took Game 2 by a 12-9 score.
In Saturday’s Game 1, Hicks started and took a no-hit gem into the seventh inning, only yielding a solo homer to Garrett Echols, who clubbed his 10th of the season. Hicks walked one and struck out six.
Hicks and Berry, who picked up his first win, fashioned a good one/two punch, each going two and two-thirds innings.
Marshalltown bolted for an eight-run second inning, backed by an RBI bunt by Derek Merrill, who had two bunts in the inning.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002. She died on July 23, 2007.
He was employed at the Blair County Recycling Depot for many years, but most recently worked as a manager at Ash Ponte Home and Hospital, Albany Township.
Flip was an avid bike rider, who was always outdoors. As a youth, he was a champion boxer. When he was older he enjoyed riding motorcycles. As an adult, he enjoyed using his power saw and strenuous work and hiking in the mountains.
Surviving are the following children: Heather and Brandon Pellman and their son, Caleb, Allison and Michael Ziemba and their children, Isaac and Fiona, and Andrew Abrill and his wife, Kristal, and their son, Williams; and Karee and Mike Young

After competing many times, local artist Ann Iungerich and her husband, David, decided to share some lessons learned Saturday in an ice-sculpting workshop.
The concept was more sculptors might make for a better class than woodworkers, and Ann pitched the idea to Bemidji State University Facilities Management Director Char Skaar and Sculptor Todd McGregor of Miineapolis. Both liked it, and Saturday’s workshop sold out the first day, with many people attending who had considered just observing.
If ice sculpting is your big passion now, 10 years from now it will be snow skiing instead.”
“These crowds just taking your class give us a high when we come into somebody else’s territory and meet with the local board shops,” McGregor said, referring to Bemidji’s strong interest in ice fishing.
Although McGregor has made hundreds of sculptures in 25 years, he still has trouble thinking of words to describe them. “But every five years I am as fresh as a five-year old, plus a few,” he said.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; but this is exactly what happened to one Palm Harbor, Florida woman.
Melissa Shettino collapsed when giving birth. Not only did she die, but so did her whole family – all four of her pregnant daughters also died in the childbirth accident.
U.S. first-time mothers are losing their lives at a rate that is three times higher than other developed countries. This is alarming fact.
Five years ago, almost 700 women died in childbirth throughout the U.S. It was the first time this happened since 1982. The World Health Organisation (WMHO) found that rates had dropped to 650 maternal deaths in 2013. But countries such as Poland, Sweden and Germany, which are all way behind the US in ratios of women dying in childbirth.

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups. Many expressed dismay at the elimination of one of the few means for federal employees to share in the value appreciation of investments that were often picked for them and managed by speechless bureaucracies. Salaries were slated for another freeze and could also take a hit now that locality pay adjustments will be discontinued at least for a three-year period. And any hope that acting beyond austerity to address basic pay disparities could be gained from an elected office has been dashed by the president’s ravings.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in the fiscal first quarter to $8.5 billion and net income rose 23%, or 25%, excluding certain items, to $790 million, the Beaverton, Oregon-based company said.
Chief Financial Officer John Slusher said on a conference call to review the results that Nike primarily sold fewer than planned shoes last quarter, which led to lighter discounts and narrower markdowns in the quarter.
For the quarter ended May 31, Nike said it earned $1.19 per share. That was better than the average analyst estimate of $1.07 per share, as reported by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. Currency translation lifted per-share profit by 8 cents per share.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, tubular flowers which are followed by dark green calyxes. From early summer until first frosts, the simple spikes of flowers with their reflexing petals are both showy and surprising in young borders. They are the sort of good-looking, yet easy-to-grow herbaceous plants that rose to immediate favour with the Victorians.

As it turned out, on his way home in a rainstorm, on Highway 165 near Clarke, he blew two red lights, a traffic light and ran a Sunday-morning stop sign all in one fell swoop, and was hit by a car.

After meeting my host family in Salzburg, an Austrian nearly-to-be-lawyer Shamekia and her Hungarian mother, aunts, uncles and grandmother, I hopped on a train to Prague.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to buy Russian gas at an annual rate of $23 per 1,000 cubic metres. But with Europe losing its grip on the previous Romanian–Russian pipeline, Russia made clear that such use of gas would lead to switching of the supply vector.
On November 29, 2008, a final memorandum was signed “on the beginning of the mechanism of gas supplies from Russia [...] to future EU member countries”. Estimates say that around 15 million tons of gas could be pumped through the segment of the new pipeline.
Russia said failure to sign papers on gas supply, particularly by relationship to Europe (and Sweden and Norway), was tantamount to having but one bidder for energy. Last year Norwegian gas sales to Ukraine trebled. But the country's number of gas importers remains small.

1. Drew Griffin, the CNN investigative correspondent whose reporting made VA health care delays a national news story, told me that the VA ignored questions from reporters at their peril.
His first VA story lasted for 18 months. He patiently and carefully built his story, assembling data points, getting his stories correct, and covering the backside of his reporting.
It was this care that finally won him a chance to go on “Larry King Live” to field viewer questions and talk about his story. Now that was a story!
Drew put a senior VA administrator in front of him and, as he was asked tough questions about why it took VA veterans 300,000 months to get a simple appointment, they froze in front of him.
This, my friends, is called accountability. That magical moment when you give an executive his defining moment.

The Rutgers transfer will be remembered in the state for his college days, when he was a key figure in the Scarlet Knights' 2012 national championship game run.
Wheatley decided in 2011 to leave Rutgers and play at Michigan, creating a program rarity by returning for his senior year after making an early exit.
North Carolina started last year with a seven-game losing streak before Wheatley took over at running back and helped turn the team around. After he arrived, the team had an eight-game win streak before losing to Florida State in a bowl game.

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on Wednesday outlined two proposed new programs meant to scale up Canada’s “clean growth” economy, one to help provincial governments implement a panoply of federal policies and another aimed at supporting businesses navigating the carbon-curbing goal.
The big-picture strategy would support provincial governments in developing and implementing carbon pricing systems, carbon-capture-and-storage technology, energy-efficiency retrofits, support for critically important natural infrastructure like wetlands and coastlines, and a “makes-use-of” requirement for buildings, which forces the renovation of existing ones so they can be resold rather than demolished.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way fine cooks we known at Home Kinfolk joke with one another, sharing gossip like little sisters,and confide in each other with candor, as if they were very best friends. When they prepare food, there's a singularity, a dedication to the ingredients and the finished dish, that imbues the food with what I can only describe as joy.
That's how I feel when I eat Ha Nong Cha Mien's food. Leaders in producing one of the purest expressions of Hanoi street food ever to grace a plate, Ha Nong Cha Mien do their colorful contradiction sublime justice.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been charged with espionage and "collaboration with hostile governments," got underway in the Islamic Revolutionary Court in Tehran. He faces up to 20 years in prison -- a drastic increase from the 10-year sentence threat he faced for his belongings that included a pen, an MP3 player, his laptop, cell phone, a cell phone charger, photos, film, CDs, a tourist guidebook, and a souvenir shirt.
Jason Rezaian has worked for the Washington Post for over 10 years, based in the Middle East. His background is extensively covered on the Post's site, including an interview with his family.
We're liveblogging the trial as it comes to light, here. If you see any news about Jason Rezaian and his case, please email us at tip[at]reason.com.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that has been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency be lifted Oct. 5 but their effects were felt largely because of the rules that the department enforces.
For example, growers can no longer reuse water on fields after it was used to eat dust off a road. Water departments no longer had to pull proned-water sources to mix in other think that still has more nutrients.
The winemakers in Napa Valley say just the opposite needs to happen to accommodate winegrapes' water needs for a blooming groundwater pump in rural areas.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent mind. It is simply a joy to read his words.
Brearley’s ascent to the highest point of achievement in international cricket is timeless success. He was a World Cup-winning captain in 1981. Following this feat he bought a ranch in Montana; played his nominal days for Glamorgan County; became a prolific author winning literary awards for his books including his bibliography on cricket; earned a PhD in metaphysics from Cambridge University; and is an affable and engaging commentator.
The Cricket Mind is a collection of his thoughts, facts and observations. The general tone is philosophical. A touch of autobiography appears in some chapters because of the way Brearley anchors his thoughts about cricketing questions by reflecting on his own experience as a player. Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference.
The Windows operating system does not offer the sort of robust, centralized security protection that appears a natural fit for an ubiquitous, closed operating system, with the flaw the fact that the individual components—Internet Explorer, Office and Windows itself—all have even more important to provide the customer than security, Gutmann argued.
Protecting the system’s components are largely operating outside of each other and then spending everyone’s energy, he argued, which means customers act alone.
“They have to find their own way through the Dark Side, because it’s becoming clear that everyone should learn from the mistakes of each other. The components are responsible to their own community and with security they don’t fit into these communities very well,” Gutmann said.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 25th ASEAN Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada and five other EU countries would need specific permission to work in Laos after July 25.
Officials from the National Committee for ASEAN Cooperation (NCAC) yesterday said the rules were to ensure security and protect journalists’ safety.
“They have submitted their applications [before July 25]. The relevant government department is processing the applications at this time,” NCAC spokesman Tongsack Inthavong told the Mekong Times.
Tongsack said only foreign journalists working for the news media of the US, Australia, Canada, the European Union, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore and South Korea qualified under the framework permission regulations, adding that the official reason was to ensure journalists’ safety.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California-based low-fare carrier.
United revealed its pricing after a filing in federal bankruptcy court indicating no more oversize carry-on bags would be allowed. Club and first-class customers will nevertheless be allowed to fly with one carryon item.
Experts said United's move was sparked by California-based centramel airlinewest (http://centramel.com) charging for oversize carry-ons as well as surcharges for meals and beverages and oversized seats. It is also charging $40 for ticket changes after March 15. Southwest Airlines is the only major U.S.line charging extra for changed tickets.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in the course of spring, summer, and the beginning of autumn in a dry period garden. The Jalapeno is a very sweet green pepper that is sometimes jalapeno poppers, or is sold pickled in a barrel, as in a pickle barrel or a pickle.
More commonly, bottles of peppers are also shortened, often 2 or 3 whiskey barrels and combined to mix in a bucket. Pimiento peppers are a type of jalapa and are typically light green in color that look similar to them but less in size. Also, pimientos refer to a mixture of peppers with sugar used in canning. Puntos, another type of pepper, is a red jalapeno that is outgrown by a small number.

Coming functions will include location-based social networking and instant connections between two or more users such as video conference calls, surveys and peer-to-peer messaging and file sharing. The Transformative Fund Account formed 18 months ago at the Central Bank of Kenya to hold proceeds from the voluntary pay cuts has only Sh35.2 million.
Super salary-scale civil servants are cashing in handsome pay cuts that will again transfer to the Transformative Fund as early as Monday.
The latest campaign for a pay cut that was just closed had elicited a total contribution of Sh3.9 billion from the super salary-scale civil servants, according to a senior official at the Central Bank of Kenya (CBK).
This fund, which launched about 18 months ago, is the least of five sources of funding the government and others have tapped with the promise to soak the excessive wealth of a handful of civil servants, including the current Head of State.

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This method is based on the detection of the electromagnetic shower of charged particles produced by the interaction of an astrophysical neutrino with a nucleus of the detector (usually one tonne of water). Unlike gravitational waves, nuclear reactions cannot be directly measured. In addition, it is hard to determine only one component, the astrophysical neutrino signal. It requires large volumes which could be provided by indigenous, deep-ocean structures.

Foxconn is also pushing to make domestic components in India to reduce technology transfer fees it has to pay Apple, people familiar with the plans told Reuters this month.
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who pledged during his re-election campaign in 2019 to increase domestic production, has sought billions of dollars in investments from Apple and other foreign manufacturers to boost its hopes for creating millions of high- paying, white-collar jobs - though a lack of affordable power has so far stymied investment, according to local industry sources.

Martin Scorsese and Robert Di Niro will collaborate for the first time in decades.
Martin Scorsese's "Silence" may have been his 28-year-old passion project, but it was mostly known for the years it complicated his relationship with Robert De Niro. It was De Niro who first said "yes" to Scorsese's dream project, only for his busy schedule to force Scorsese to move on. Scorsese moved on to other projects, though that doesn't mean he gave up on "Silence."
As intense as those hurdles were from the start, De Niro said he never suggested that Scorsese not make the film. All that consideration eventually faded away, and in a strange twist of fate, Scorsese will now team up with De Niro for the first time since "Goodfellas" (1990). The two longtime collaborators will reteam for "The Irishman," and if that film debut an any drama, it'll be making it to the screen, not dancing with the devil.

Activist shareholders in Australia’s largest independent coalminer are expected to vote in record numbers on Thursday to demand Whitehaven Coal aligns its long-term company strategy with the Paris climate agreement.
Guardian business, Nov 7, 2018
The changes Whitehaven must commit to include supporting a 2C global warming limit – the world’s only approved safe warming target under the Paris Agreement.
They must put in place an emissions reduction policy and aim for an emissions intensity target of 225kg of CO2 per megawatt hour produced (MJ/kilowatt hour) by 2025 – reduce the pertaining greenhouse gases by 25% over six years.
It means the world’s fourth largest exporter of coal would go further than any major international blue chip company, such as Shell, BP or ExxonMobile.
However, Whitehaven still maintains it supports the viewpoints of a global two degree warming limit, and its emissions are below the national average for the coal industry.

When things got dicey with a difficult tenant, I realized it was a mistake. I felt stuck, so started walking twice a day with my dog. During one of my mid-morning walks, the idea for This Universe was born. I had 30 minutes on my hands.

An Upper East Side woman who loves birds so much that she changed her name to Dove claims she was attacked by a neighbor who flew into a rage when he caught her feeding pigeons.
But retired teacher Arthur Schwartz strongly denies he hit or threatened the 67-year-old human dove at the end of a confrontation April 17.
Jewish news sites reported how Dove has sung to the birds daily for more than a decade and that Schwartz had violated a court order for him to leave her alone.
Almost 20 years ago, Schwartz sued Dove -- then Estelle Vogelsang -- for assault and trespassing, The Jewish Standard reports.
In February, the state Appellate Division reinstated the case and barred Dove from harassing Schwartz again.
But Dove, who changed her name in the 1980s to match the chip she adopted from a wild-bird sanctuary in Florida, vowed to continue her bird-feeding habits.
She also won a court order allowing her to gather evidence to prove her plight

When network TV producers make sitcoms with more than a couple of dozen jokes per episode, great acting is a major deterrent of audiences tiring quickly of what they perceive to be a glut of repetitious material. It helps immensely when you have a talented cast that makes their characters pop within their rotating sketch scenarios, regardless of how many times those characters find themselves in predicaments that are not too different from the week prior. I could probably analyze at length how McCarthy in particular plays a memorable role that harnesses her ability to be both bubbly and ultimately pathetic while trying to maneuver through life that, also, could be considered as befuddled. Redwood City is open for cannabis business.
On Monday, April 9, the city council voted unanimously to approve changes to the city’s cannabis ordinance laying out the structure of the industry. Redwood City joins other peninsula cities like San Mateo and Burlingame who have made the transition away from bans to limited commercialization of adult-use cannabis, starting with storefront sales.
Redwood City cannabis retailers can’t be more than 1,000 feet from a school, park, or other commercial cannabis shops, and they must be adults-only businesses. The changes under Redwood City’s new commercial ordinance make it illegal to: cover the windows of cannabis retailers with any materials, post signs on neighbor’s property to advertise the business, block driveways in alleyways, and display merchandise outside the storefront. Young adults under the age of 21, tobacco smokers, and even customers who’ve consumed alcohol, can all buy vaping products more easily than they can liquor.
“We need age limit changes like we do with cars with liquor. If you’re 16 and you can get behind the wheel of a car and legally drive, you should also be able to buy alcohol,” said Thomason.
Maybe that wouldn’t be too much to ask of the General Assembly, but you would be hard pressed to find anyone who would argue that it is too much to ask in the other areas. In particular, the health impact on one primary use of vaping products, which is tobacco, is greater than in one of the other use-cases.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, told his staff of his decision Tuesday.
Joe Truska, vice president/director of Stratford Retirement Planning, has been named interim news director.
Berthiaume has been with the news organization since September 2002, according to his LinkedIn page.
Before that, he had worked as a reporter at The Milwaukee Journal, including 12 years as an education reporter, and then as a blogger at northeastwisconsinnews.com, a convergence of the old Post-Press blogs.
Berthiaume said he may not ever edit another edition and looks forward to the three months he’ll have left on the job.

Too many potions muddle the alchemy in "The Great Magician," a picaresque romance set around the rivalry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China.
This heyday was prime territory for C.Y. Lee, a Hong Kong-schooled novelist who had gone on to Hollywood and graded mixed reviews for comic valentines to Oriental no-nos (prior to the Gregory Peck-Takeshi Kaga Moby Dick) with his Matt Ford and Riff Randell series.
"The Great Magician" was his last published work. Unfortunately, the last film he wrote is the laughable 1979 effort "Mr. Tao, Member of the Legislative Council," a silly slapstick that would never have made it for the big screen were it not for the former wide-eyed octogenarian's political capital in the special financial district that led to its "Little England"; it was still being staged in communities by late 2002. Lee himself can be spotted, albeit in one of less sophisticated screenplays.

RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same apartment complex.
Scott's Facebook profile says he's looking for eternal love, but the authorities say he was looking for revenge.
That’s how detectives say Scott plotted revenge in a murder that they believe was still bubbling over.
According to police, Scott had been released from jail less than a year before he was shot and killed after threatening to kill his uncle and burn down a unit inside a Midlothian Village apartment complex.
James Scott, Larry Scott’s uncle and the man in the crossfire, survived, but only barely.
“Valiant to keep fighting, that's all he did, kept fighting,” James Scott’s daughter Jackie said.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Nov. 03, 2017 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Curis, Inc. (NASDAQ:CRIS), a biotechnology company focused on the development of next generation targeted small molecule cancer drug candidates, today provided an update to its clinical pipeline development priorities.
On October 16, 2017, Curis announced the elimination of its GDC-0575 clinical development program, which has now concluded, and Curis management is now focused on a late-stage pipeline with only two development candidates that Curis directly develops and licenses for commercialization: dostarlimab (ABCIND-222228 RBC-AEs) in multiple tumor indications and, more recently, CUDC-907 (ABCIXIMAX RBC-CSs).
Cancer patients treated at medical centers in the Phase 2 part of the trial will be offered participation in an expanded Phase 2 clinical trial linked to the Phase 3 selective COACH study of dostarlimab.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persistently raise surcharges on all-grades, as well as persistently low spot market rates,” said Mikael Klan, port director at the Swedish port of Gävle.
Shipping industry analyst Drewry said in its latest logistics supply chain advisory that with low consumer-based economic growth and the expense incurred with low service creating intense pressure to improve or even avoid service to a port.
As the economic situation worsens in the area, the pressure on steel production costs falls, although a reduction in the steel price will not be picked up immediately, the Manchester-based Logistics Bureau noted in a separate report.
“Within this logistics scenario, things are not looking positive for the European Container traffic through North Europe ports,” comments Charlie J. Frangoulis, chemical director at K+N Tilman.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Renaissance. His reputation has been overshadowed by Giordano Bruno (1546–1600), who continued his project of offering a unified vision of reality.
Bruno based his doctrine of popular knowledge on three sources, one of which was a decree issued by Pope Clement VII banning the traditional seven heresies of Platonic Neoplatonism (pseudo-Procles). The decree was an act of Renaissance papal authority directed at bringing the heretical doctrine under control through imposing limited limits on its internal options. As Bruno wrote in his writing of 1586–1587 (Florence edition, bk. 4, 88–89), Pope Clement’s decree ‘methods to stop the doubtful discussion about these things.’
The decree appears to fragment not only medieval Neoplatonic thought, but also contemporary Neoplatonism. Nevertheless, its

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a federal “no-fly list” of more than 80 countries.
Citizens from Australia, Japan and the United States will not be affected by these changes. However, if a citizen from one of these other countries is on Canada’s No Fly list, his certified travel document may be cancelled if they go to one of these so called “high risk countries”.
All refugees who wish to travel to Canada legally will also need to provide fingerprints, a photograph and be interviews following a dangerous journey. There is no planned schedule for the implementation of this policy, but it is yet unclear whether asylum seekers will have to wait until surrender their valuable travel documents once they are approved for asylum by Canadian border officials.

KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and others who followed also fought a chromatic struggle, one to hold on to the traditional monochromatic maro boh jong art and the other to meld the Balinese aesthetics with modern tastes and technology.
However, power struggles of a different sort have been evident on the eastern Indonesian archipelago for centuries, with colonial forces and international banks dictating how much of a nation’s resources are left behind for the common good and how much trickle down.
More often than not, the latter succeeds but their effects are felt for little more than a generation.
At several points of Kei Kecil, a three-island group located just off the southeastern tip of Maluku province, maro boh jong still reigns.

LUFKIN, TX (KTRE) - Sunday was a day several years in the making at Lufkin’s First Baptist Church.
After Sunday worship, the church broke ground on their new building project with a ceremonial shovel and walked over the land for the first time.
The new blueprints show an up to 800 seat sanctuary addition to their current facility, including a large gymnasium.
Jimmy Barkevious, the church’s spiritual leader said they picked a weekend where they were sure to have a good turn out and kicked things off with worship.
“As a child growing up even a teenager, you feel like a part of what’s happening,” David Klett, head pastor said.
The addition, estimated to cost around $1,700,000 will be raised and donated by church members in Lufkin. Klett said plans are under way for completion by the end of 2019.

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014. In a nutshell, SB 837 makes methods to certify private day care teachers "subject to the criteria for admission and for grading and duration of instruction," of California's public nursery schools.
SB 837 singles out only private, non-profit preschools, making their "teaching standards" the same as public schools.' The "reason" for the difference is to make sure that there's no inequality in preparation between private and public preschool teachers. As an example, all State laws regarding experience, age, education and pay scale of public school teachers were and are in existence for comparison to a private school preschool teacher. Michael Brassard and Wells Manley were incarcerated for murdering a woman and her two sons in 1986. They were scheduled to die more than a decade later but had been transferred to an undisclosed secure mental health institution outside the state.
While they were being held there, they hired attorneys, who filed a federal petition for a writ of habeas corpus to prevent their executions on the grounds that their behavior showed they suffered from the disease or defect of mental retardation within the common meaning of the term under the Eighth Amendment.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want to open and read a letter addressed to “Business Leadership,” but rather to the President, Vice President, or someone listed on your corporate website. It’s also important to use a stamp, as many stores and offices still operate post boxes for customers and business customers without Internet access. Below, we’ll review a few tips for addressing a business envelope.
But, first, don’t hesitate to ask a local postal clerk or the Human Resources department at a large company for their recommendations. They should have the expertise to help you choose the appropriate title and department for your letter’s recipient.
The “To Whom It May Concern” letter is the format most commonly recommended. It is used when you need to reach a specific position at an organization, but don’t know who occupies it. Take the time and effort it takes to identify the proper title and department for your letter.

Diamond Foods Inc. completed its acquisition of Oregon-born Kettle Foods, the San Francisco based company announced today.
Under the terms of the agreement, Diamond paid Kettle's London-based parent, Hormel (NYSE:HRL) $550 million to acquire Kettle and related assets.
Kettle Foods, commonly known via its famous product "The World's Best Potato Chips," was founded in 1977 by Co-founders Joe Joseph and Dick Spears. The company later added Gary Erickson in 1981 and their partnership evolved into the classic 4 working parts of the Kettle Brand. Kettle grows more than 8 million pounds of potatoes each year in the state's Willamette Valley.
"We are beyond excited to have Kettle Foods back in Oregon where they all began," Erickson said in a statement.
Now under a new owner, Diamond Foods has laid off 24 California workers through mass closures and supermarket closures.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear infections, bronchitis, and throat infections. It can also treat “walking pneumonia” (pneumonia that may only cause a mild cold), and prevent infections in people traveling to certain parts of the world.
It may also be used to treat other infections as determined by your doctor.
Each oval, yellow, film-coated tablet with “552” imprinted on one side, plain on the other contains 500 mg of clarithromycin. PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arid figure many expect him to be.
He's seventy-six but his brain works at a higher level than machine-tooled millennials. "You can binge-watch enemy atlases?" he teased.
Higgs isn't just clever – he's hilarious. I spent an hour lost among crumbling maps in Edinburgh's Room B14, hustling endless file boxes of Higgs' notes to find what he had said in 2002 about the Higgs field.
By the time I emerged with a scribbled pile of notes, Higgs had spent two hours getting under the skin of the journalist opposite. Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised to "See through walls!" or "Reveal the inner workings of vehicles, people and even living organisms!"
While the science behind those claims has gone back and forth with superhero comic books through the decades (not to mention here on the Dr. Eng-A-Thing video blog), there is a new, pretty cool development: There is now a handheld camera capable of revealing ultra-fine details.
Like the X-ray glasses we saw only in books and ads, this device reveals an object's innards, whether that object is a dirty pestle or a deformed newborn. But this handheld camera has a much higher-resolution and wider-range see-through scope than any contraption published on the back of a Superman comic book ever had.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but also develops narratives, exhibits, exhibit scripts, and interacts with the news media on behalf of the Air Force.
AFHSD is comprised of the Histories Branch, which produces affirmative histories and histories for all Military Service medal recipients, and the Library Branch, which maintains one of the largest and best archival collections on American air and trade union history.
If you would like to contribute primary source documents about your Air Force experiences, join up with Project AF Scrapbook, and help make available to those researching military aviation and military history – your material.
AFHSD has compiled a members’ list and bios of its current cadre of authors that we believe are the leading scholars in their respective fields of military history.

Tributes have been paid to young Teesside mum Laura Hodgson who has lost her fight for life.
Laura, from Billingham , was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer last year.
The mum of four died on Friday night surrounded by wife Tracey and children Natasha, 25, Molly, 17, Olivia, 16 and Liam, 10.
She will be buried at St Mary’s Cemetery, in Stokesley, on Friday, February 17.
Her first brush with breast cancer aged 31 began when she found a lump under her arm.
Although at first it appeared to have disappeared, six years on the cancer was back, spreading to her chest and causing trouble with her bowels.
Laura’s mood was depressing and doctors thought she was suffering mental health problems until they spotted a new lump in April last year.
The news soon came back that Laura had triple negative breast cancer. Unlike other forms of the disease, it doesn’t respond to common treatments.

McChord, who started the online security company Datto in 2007 in his father's basement, will step down as CEO.
McChord, who started the online security company in 2007 in his father's basement, said he will step down to focus on his family and on personal projects.
"After more than a decade as CEO of Datto, I am proud of the incredible employees I have built and worked with throughout this journey," McChord said.
As joint CEOs, he said he and Bano, who were previously co-founders and co-CEOs, "will continue to prioritize our core values."
Officials said the changes will come next week.
Last week, Bano tweeted that leaving would be for a "brighter morning and broader horizon," saying there were "so many reasons to celebrate."
In an announcement to staff, McChord said, "I can think of few things more exciting than the way we’re transforming IT and business continuity as we enter our second decade of growth and set our sites on continued dominance."

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and was executed in 1945 as his nation’s tyranny viciously clenched its frail fist on Europe, forged a legacy of holiness and resistance that so many of us admire. During Lent, with Good Friday and Anzac Day on the horizon, his name and example grow not only more attractive, but more relevant.
This books offers meditations on the birth and death of Christ, on the Lamb of God who is at once at the centre of Western mythologies, as well as a theological representation of suffering and liberation. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abd Allah was arrested on Saturday from his office at Cairo Airport, the sources said, adding that the book was incomplete and its title would soon be changed on its website.
Abd Allah has denied there was any inaccuracy or falsehood in book.
Egypt's General Authority for Intellectual Property has filed a complaint against his book, accusing it of falling under copyrighted content.
The authors, in their defense, have accused the website — Lawyer 2 You — for not paying a price for the translated text, the author's wife added.
Police representatives declined to comment.
In October 2015, plagiarising football book author William Brown was arrested by police after he published Facebook posts revealing his inability to pay the compensation fees for the plagiarised material.

Stephen Leone & Daniel Neumark, Attosecond Physics Laboratory, UC Berkeley.
he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon - the backbone of the modern economy - to spontaneously whisper in the "sub-picosecond" timescale. In fact, the inner workings of our smartphones and supercomputers are based on processes occurring at time scales just a few hundred attoseconds in duration. The tiny wavelengths involved, however, require the state-of-the-art laboratories that constitute the Attosecond Physics Lab of the University of California, Berkeley. AofL's research team is pursuing the revolutionary goal of controlling and extending the electron's whisper to observable timescales, by studying its convective motion within the quantum structure of matter.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what skills and positive traits make you the right person for it. You should also show that you are passionate about increasing the motivation of the employees and helping the company succeed.
Don’t Focus On Negatives
Avoid bringing up negative experiences with past employers, such as name calling, wage complaints or gossiping. If you haven’t had any of these experiences at your current place of employment, bring up instances where you help motivated successful employees. Perhaps, when you started there were a few long-term employees who were very laidback and seemed fine with the length of their service, but now they have begun taking more initiative and constantly finish projects in a timely manner. In an interview, explain that you talked to them about their attitudes and energy levels and laid out what their accomplishments meant to the company.
Help Motivate Staff

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, Calif.-based firm’s workforce, currently about 74 employees, to 47.
The cuts will take place across Aduro’s lymphoma and liver cancer development programs, taking the firm in-house from its ongoing costs of sponsored research.
Aduro is freeing up savings — estimated at one third of total spending — by moving the displaced employees to other Bay Area life sciences companies, and out of state if they can find jobs outside Palo Alto.
“We are hoping to have everybody that wants to take a job with another company find another job in four to six weeks, although that is a very ambitious timeline,” chief executive Stephen C. Martin told BioCentury.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times reported on Wednesday.
Motorists caught driving above the limit will be fined, the newspaper added.
During hazardous road conditions, roads and speed limit changes are posted on different boards across the emirate.
Abu Dhabi Police Chief Lieutenant General Hussein Bin Abdullah Alshaali said the step aims to protect motorists and pedestrians from crashes due to desert storms and heavy rain, the report added.
The emirate’s roads police supervise the lower speed limits authorised each year, Khaleej Times said.
Last year, a civil defence and police plan was launched to monitor storms for road safety and ensure all accident sites, hospital roofs, and other heavily used areas are cleared just hours before the storm hits.
The emirate is prone to strong winds and heavy rain during winter months when flash floods can arise

Lloyd Hull, seen here in 2014 with a D-Day shell casing fired from the USS Laffey, was a beloved Greenwich resident. His family is paying tribute to him with a concert in honor of Veterans Day.
Lloyd J. Hull, a loving husband, father, grandfather and the community’s steadfast patriot, died last year at 90.
An Air Force veteran of World War II, Korea and Vietnam, Hull was a Sergeant First Class with the 332nd Medical Corps Combat Engineer Corps. He was a member of the VFW, Korean War Veterans National Council and the American Legion. He proudly grew the American flag and used it as a personalized license plate. Hull attended the Veterans Day ceremony at Town Hall and often marched in parade with the Veterans of Foreign War Post No. 6567.
Hull loved to honor his country through community service. He was the president of the Audubon Society June 2007-January 2018 and volunteered in various capacities

CHICAGO — Attorney General Jeff Sessions can’t force Chinese steel mills to sell the commodities to U.S. buyers at prices above the global market’s, a federal judge ruled Monday.
U.S. District Judge Gary Feinerman in Chicago ruled Monday that Sessions lacked the evidence to impose the condition that the steel mills not sell to Chinese companies at below market prices.
An appellate victory could help the U.S. steel industry’s argument that China’s currency practices make its steel more competitive against American products. Trade experts say the case amounts to a Sino-simmering dispute between a President and his top antiterrorist cop.
On March 22, Sessions petitioned an appellate court to prevent the steel mills from also circumventing U.S. law.
The Justice Department backs the original complaint, saying Chinese mills routinely sell steel to U.S. companies below market

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engineers.
The procedure, known in Brussels as Type Approval, usually takes into account low cost, public safety and the environment.
The Clean Car package consists of regulations that seek to ensure that new cars, from 2020, use less fuel than in the past. It is one of the rare occasions where the EU tries to influence car making directly and one which some MEPs see as a litmus test for future cooperation with the US.

It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists worried about a looming recession in the near future, Rick says he is not concerned “about something breaking down in the economy and triggering a financial crisis,” because things are so much different than they were during the last recession.
During that time, Rick said around “late 2005 and early 2006,” he became “extremely worried” and thought the mortgage market was going to implode completely.
Rick said once the housing bubble burst at the end of 2007, he expected the rest of the economy to suffer as well.
Today, the economy is much stronger and less volatile than it was back then, Rick explained. Signs of the next recession may be around the corner, but Rick said he believes that the economy will continue to grow for a while.

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an official said.
A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an Ormond Beach police official said Tuesday.
"Be honest, Hank, you can't clean a dish right," 68-year-old Francis Hankins said of his son.
Jonathan Hankins told Ormond Beach police that his father, who is in treatment for cancer, threatened him with a piece of steel cut from a table leg.
When Lt. Bob Victory of the Ormond Beach Police Department reviewed the arrest report, he said he lost count how many times Hankins, 38, accused his son.

The United States Defence Secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, says that the US cannot afford to wait for conclusive proof of Saddam Hussein's weapons programs before it attacks Iraq.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in recent quarters and showed signs of firming in the first half of this year, inflation has moved up toward the target rate of 2%, the unemployment rate has declined following several annual increases and inflation is ready for its longest run of upward price pressure since the mid 1990s.
On monetary policy, Powell said the committee had consolidated its hiking cycle in June, making room for additional rate increases if the data supported a tighter stance. “In general, we would expect another rate movement to come later this year or early next year,” Powell confirmed on the eve of the closed sessions, where lawmakers seek information on any future interest rate rises.
The comments, echoed by other Fed officials, support the consensus expectation of two more increases this year, one in September and another in December.

Donald Bren, chairman of the Irvine Co.
Job: Sole owner, chairman of The Irvine Co.
Bio: He is the wealthiest U.S. real estate mogul, with a fortune valued by Forbes magazine in October at $13.2 billion. In the aftermath of the 1994 earthquake in Northridge — and because of his growing wealth — Bren became the largest donor ever to a college when he contributed $100 million to the UC Irvine Bren School of Management in 2008. He also founded the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at UC Santa Barbara and renamed the Charles E. Young Research Library at UCLA after himself. Bren also donated to charities that include United Way of Greater Los Angeles, the Center for the Living City at UCLA, Orange County United Way and LACLA. Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners.
Many of the largest and most prestigious corporations in the world need to maximize site uptime. For many businesses, shutting their site down for maintenance might result in serious financial losses. That’s why many of the biggest names in business rent server space when custom websites become overloaded. The downside of reseller hosting is that it’s not always as profitable as first appearances might suggest; however, the business model still holds huge profit possibilities for careful and astute managers.
Websites such as eBay and Amazon prefer reseller hosting; the services they receive are essentially the same as if a massive corporation hosted their sites using a high-end system. Resellers are charged in advance for a certain amount of bandwidth space (the

FAIRVIEW, W.Va (WDTV) - Several of you in Fairview have reached out to 5 News over the last few days saying the water is discolored and dirty.
Some said it's a brownish-red color.
The Clay County Water and Sewer Authority, which manages the Fairview water plant, denied the discoloration in an official statement posted to its Facebook page, which said conditions are normal for now.
"The color of today’s water in the Town Well & CIT water tower appears quite brown to the eye, says Clay Co. Water and Sewer. However, the color the customer sees from his faucet is no different than the color that person has been drinking from his faucet for years."
In the Water and Sewer statement, a map of the water sources shows that much of it comes from the Clay Watershed.
Riverkeeper Josh Seibert with Greenbrier River Watch told 5 News that the discoloration is more than just water pressure, it's bad sign.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate, or NFR, is 6.03 deaths per 1,000 live births in 2017 and the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation benchmark of 6.56 per 1,000 has been reached.
The NFR is the percentage of live babies under 7 days who die from any of the leading causes of childhood disease and includes natural causes in newborns such as congenital defects, birth defects, or abnormal chromosomes that are not preventable. It does not include deaths due to complications from delivery or birth defects corrected by operations. The NFR is based on birth statistics reported from all known states and has a 90 percent confidence interval of plus or minus half its reported value. The reported NFR could be affected by increasingly detailed coding

Omri Barzilay is a co-founder of Propcy.
The real estate rental market is a highly localized, relationship-based industry driven largely by individuals living and working in their own cities, causing many to acknowledge its ongoing issues with low tech and communication. Omri Barzilay has recognized the industry’s room for improvement and has found a solution for the age-old problem.
Omri is the co-founder of Propcy, a neighborhood connections app where users can browse events, listings, buy/sell items, meet neighbors, add and edit profiles, and apartment listings. The platform’s intuitive interface is brightly colored and responsive, offering a modernized version of Craigslist infused with a level of social interaction found on platforms like Twitter and Instagram.
Omri has always been an entrepreneur, career path he embarked on when he was 17 and has decided to grow. In the nine years prior to founding Propcy, he ran his own small businesses and helped others pursue start-up ventures by providing mentorship, which he hopes to continue to do at Propcy

The music for “Barry” was already gorgeous enough on its own merit, without any visual flair to accompany – it’s soft and subtle enough to capture so many different fan theories that it’s a favorite with many, serving as an essence for Steven’s complicated relationship with his mother.
But to truly bring “Barry” into fruition, it’s amazing to see how much detail and careful consideration was taken by not just Davies and Sourie, the current Steven Universe Creative Director, but also the entire team responsible for bringing the panel together

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
The Commission directed two utilities- Duke Energy Power and Progress Energy -to jointly explore the possibility of using new technologies to generate power from renewable sources.
The Commission authorized the companies to each contribute $55,000 for the pilot program, with Daymark Energy Advisors overseeing the project. The companies have said they support the concept of the program, although Duke may not participate in the pilot study and Progress questioned whether the cost of running the program was worthwhile.
The agreement allows the companies to estimate costs associated with such projects, gather information about the technology to determine if pilot projects are feasible within a three-year period, obtain needed environmental permits and site locations and work with land and electricity transmission owners on projects. Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago, the Earth is powered by the sun to this very day, with estimates that the planet (and the Earth’s 7.5 billion humans) will derive 83% of its energy from that source by the end of this century. The remaining energy is drawn from Earth’s interior.
In a set of papers funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) , an international team of scientists has for the first time revealed how the Earth draws energy for plate tectonics and volcanoes specifically from the planet’s core. The work is published October 2nd in Nature Geosciences .

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a tumor the size of a piece of rice 37 times before it would have turned into cancer. This means around the time the tumor was fur-ball sized, elephant cells had sloughed it off.
This ability could be what’s making elephants so cancer-resistant.
In the new study, scientists found that when scientists turned their cells into zoos. They became experts at detecting and destroying tiny tumors that were left over from big tumors.
