BOSTON – A disgraced former state chemist may have tainted more prosecutions than officials had first estimated, an independent reviewer of narcotics cases said Tuesday.
More than 400 convictions of criminal defendants may have been tainted because of former state lab worker Annie Dookhan’s alleged misconduct, Administrative Judge Joyce Conti said Tuesday. Of those convictions, 90 were overturned, and 123 had suspicious findings, Conti said at a legislative hearing.
Dookhan was an assistant district attorney in Boston in the 1980s and 1990s. Her case became a national cause célèbre when the Innocence Project and The National Registry of Exonerations both listed her as the prosecutor in the largest number of overturned convictions. Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the University of Wisconsin, Madison, and The University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, conducted the study to assess the effects of yoga on cortical brain activity. To measure activity, participants were monitored with electroencephalography (EEG)—electric recordings of brainwave activity—while yoga positions were substituted for typical physical activities.
While initial EEG readings showed spikes in brainwaves associated with the alpha rhythm when either simple drawing or moderate cycling activity were used to relax muscles, no significant fluctuations in alpha waves were detected in EEG readings when yoga was used to exercise and relax muscles. The differences with yoga versus cycling and drawing were revealed when participants engaged in hatha yoga postures. For the yoga group, alpha rhythms rapidly decreased and followed an exponential decay curve. Scientists concluded that yoga generates a significant amount of electricity, more than previous studies

“Market Forces undertook a detailed analysis of 22 large Australian listed companies encompassing all the major energy utilities, mining companies and the big four banks with respect to their climate change risk exposure,” Ben Oquist of Market Forces said.
“Even though much of the energy sector is heavily exposed to long-lived fossil fuel assets, they still face risks of bankruptcy if climate change action delivers as promised in Paris. They need your super or retail savings to continue funding their business activity,” he added.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data series comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the winter ice off the northwestern coast of Russia. Early charts record sea ice edge positions and concentrations, and are useful for analyzing trends in the extent of Arctic sea ice and the length of the ice season.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to store water better, all while reinvigorating the soil and improving plant growth.
Since yard and kitchen waste make up about one-fourth of all garbage in the United States, compost can significantly reduce the amount of garbage that is being deposited each year. In short, compost is a value-added way to reduce waste, conserve resources, and decrease consumption.
Many households use compost toilets that require a “flush” by first composting toilet paper and then pouring water into the toilet to keep the so-called “cooking chamber” from smelling. Other houses separate wet waste from dry and dry waste is either buried or disposed of. In all cases, having the ability to reduce wastes will benefit your health and your garden.
Composting is an old technology that can provide powerful solutions to new problems.

Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board ordered companies like Chugach Distillery, Lodi Distilling Co., Glacier Spirits and Alaska Distilling Co. to stay within the letter of the so-called direct-to-consumer business model. Direct-to-consumer laws allow distilleries and other alcohol businesses to serve samples of drinks for tastings or events.
Mixed drinks, however, aren't considered samples.
Board members' decision came down almost two years to the day that the family-owned Loki Distilling Co. of Eagle River was denied a liquor sales license by the board. Its owner, Melanie Rush, is a member of the American Indian leader Edward Thomas Sr., and wrote to the board that the company would be especially hurt by the board voting to prohibit customers from sampling mixed drinks. Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow. He had survived stroke-related paralysis.
But Karnow is best remembered for writing the book Vietnam: A History, which he spent the better part of two decades in research and writing. First published in 1983 with and a hefty price tag, the 748-page magnum opus won the National Book Award, a Pulitzer, and a number of awards from other organizations.
Long before that, though, Karnow had already achieved national recognition for a pair of documentaries, "The Uncounted Enemy" and "Portrait of Vietnam," both produced by Encyclopædia Britannica Films. Airing more than 100 times on NBC-TV in 1966, the films chronicled both the war in Vietnam

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with a minimal amount of risk. Decision trees, also known as classifying trees or decision algorithms, use logic to display a series of choices that can be used to achieve the goals. A well-constructed decision tree is a systematic way of assessing risk, estimating the probability of success, and identifying tradeoffs between benefits and potential losses.
Decision trees become useful as they apply a minimal amount of calculation to each of the branches connecting a set of choices. Branches emerge from the central point of path to take a person to a best-case scenario. Main branches emerge from the center list, then develop more complex branches.
A decision tree's main branches would match the choices, such as ignoring a potential client, focusing on marketing the new product, or closing rather than opening new retail stores. In the new client situation, for example, the main branches include ignoring

The latest Conference Board Consumer Confidence Report showed that consumer sentiment rose sharply to 101.5 from 98.1 in January, exceeding forecaster expectations.

The much anticipated JOLTS (Job Openings Labor Turnover Survey) figures on Wednesday showed that there were 4.0 million vacant jobs as of the end of December, which was just a slight decrease from the previous year and better than economists' expectation.

The town will now consider changing its animal ordinance.
A Berlin woman is trying to keep her pet goat despite a town ordinance.
A dwarf goat named Benny has been living in a backyard pen at 3 Chestnut Street in Berlin for the past year. But today she may have to leave unless the town changes its animal ordinance.
"You can have a dog do its business [in the backyard]. It's not as bad as it used to be," said Faye Meucci, who lives on Chestnut Street. She also said that the town's current animal ordinance needs to be updated.
The ordinance bans any non-domestic elephants, zebras and camels. It also bans goats, rabbits, chickens and turkeys that weigh more than 10 pounds; it bans more than three bees; it bans more that three ducks.
A poll was posted to the town's Facebook page this week to ask whether people want the town's animal ordinance changed. According to the Bergen Record newspaper, about 200 people have commented so far.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, found that among women who reported having intimate interactions with paternal or male relatives as fully engaged grandmothers, those over 60 were no more likely to be violent when angry than low-interaction grandmothers their age or younger. But among women who had interacted with maternal or female relatives as grandmothers, older, high interaction grandmothers were not only less likely to be violent than those with less interaction with them, but they also reported fewer anger-provoking experiences compared with low-interaction grandmothers.
Study author Anna K. Matson, a postdoctoral fellow at The Kinsey Institute and the Indiana Institute on Disability and Community at Indiana University, was drawn to these findings because she noticed that her mother-in-law faded into the background when she was angry.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2013. The company is working with the community so improvements become available across all open source distributions and not just Hortonworks’ distribution.
Between the two projects, significant improvements have been made to Hive, sustaining a 25x speed increase over known performance issues. Hive now performs faster than other Hadoop analytics solutions in some cases.
Hortonworks has also created a public, living GitHub project containing Hive, opt-in features related to Stinger.next. Everyone is able to contribute ideas and feedback even if they’re not already contributing code. Individual community members are still working on base-level fixes as well.
To complement these projects and provide leadership on the next generation of Hive, the Apache Hive project is seeking a Vice President.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given. But what about small and midsized businesses? What opportunities exist for them to leverage free and open-source applications for the most basic business applications such as accounting, payroll, human capital management and enterprise resource planning?
One enterprise resource planning application that is seeing some traction is OpenMFG (Open Manufacturing Framework for Enterprises), an open-source ERP (enterprise resource planning) application developed by the open-source ERP specialists at Lexicon, a Montpellier, France-based managed software company.
OpenMFG ERP, released under OpenSoftware Foundation licensing to GPLv2 plus Alpha+ license, promises a rich software stack for small and midsized businesses looking for an open-source-based ERP, not involving costs for software, maintainers, or additional human resources taken away from real business processes.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you like in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might otherwise cause them to exit. All have heard of the $1,000 trading seminar that got one of the traders involved, and you know the usual line - “trade only when (after they have examined your portfolio or credit history). This is of course the golden rule in trading.
The problem with this approach is that after establishing the entry conditions, there is nothing more to do. It’s only a matter of time before humans will get weary of following a mechanical process. Forex trading is mechanical in nature in the sense that you will change the products you trade, the market conditions may change, so may the time of day to do something. ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with UPC Switzerland.
From April 15, Sunrise will enter exclusive negotiations with UPC on a potential deal that would improve their prospects on Switzerland's competitive pay-TV and broadband market, but any deal would ultimately require approval from shareholders and Swiss telecom watchdog CCC.
The attempt by Sunrise's main shareholder to block an extension of its "blank cheque" on fresh capital could complicate efforts by Sunrise chief lawyer Rene Oberaumer to persuade the other shareholders to back the merger plans, analysts and sources with direct knowledge of the plans said.
Credit Suisse Sachs' head of strategic investors Daniel Leiz said the surprise move shows an unwillingness among the minority shareholders to back the merger path and more likely leads the way towards a sale of Sunrise.

While specific incidents involving police violence – from the killing of Mike Brown in Ferguson, MO, to the death of Eric Garner on Staten Island – have been highlighted in protests all over the country since the summer, the issue of racial inequality is rarely debated. And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. From how we appraise accidents, to fear of burglars, to how we perceive the movements and activities of others, subconscious beliefs about race can intrude on all areas of life.
Social psychologist Samuel Bailey examined the idea in 2011 as part of his doctoral research. Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations is being done on the basis of a "data-driven" approach. Of course valid data is essential to helping reduce risks and create positive outcomes, but to focus solely on the data can lead to some important pitfalls.
For one, it can detract from the human aspect, the perception that there is not much room to change a course that is already set. Risk lied calculated until the clock is ticking. As a result, the feeling that data is king and that decisions are data-driven sometimes results in issues falling through the cracks. And even when all of the technical skills and perfection of analytical process are applied, your analysis remains risky . It's human nature. Nothing is fool-proof - including technology.
Progress happens one small experiment at a time
Ongoing experimentation and learning is important, but much of it is person-specific and may not be the focus of a risk analysis.

ENT specialists are aplenty and ear buds too have been around for quite some time, but many Delhiites still love to get their ears cleaned by the traditional ear-cleaners.
Ear cleaning is one of the most ancient medical disciplines in India. Ear cleaning by way of putting a few drops of essential oils and applying a cloth is the only aspect of ear cleaning that falls under the purview of standard allopathic medicine. The rest of the act of earwashing is considered as non-allopathic. The practice of ear washing dates back to mythological times and this form of treatment is still followed by a majority of people all over the country. You can consult your nearest ENT specialist from one of the listing of EENT clinics in Delhi.
Earwashing carried out by retired and licensed mud therapists was more widespread in the urban areas, especially in Mumbai and Chennai, but its popularity has been declining. The superstitious belief was that earwashing will improve one's hearing and hearing power.

Everybody got a little hot under the collar this week as European Council president Donald Tusk became the latest to let his frustration with the United Kingdom get the better of him, suggesting that “a special place in hell” awaits Britain for its decision to leave the European Union.
Were it possible to discern relevant differences in views between Germans and Americans, Mr. Tusk’s comment might be seen as an example of how polarization, institutions and a pluralistic view of the world are different in Europe compared to the US. In the US we say a comment is offensive when it is seen as hurtful and potentially harmful. In other policy places however there are times when such comments are considered legitimate deliberations of disagreement.
The German newspapers, about which there is less emphasis given to harsh words, are quicker then broadcasters to call a comment offensive, and much quicker than the US media which typically does not as such comments become the focus on cable shows and social media. While there are no independent, mainstream German cable-news channels per se, broadcast journalists focus many of its shows each night about such discussions.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens’ knowledge of key scientific concepts and understanding of their significance. Overall, the survey suggested that most people know very little about core scientific principles. Further, the people who did well on the quiz tended to be college bound, white and relatively affluent.
When the public was asked about what science has contributed in terms of new technologies and innovations, most people were unable to fill in the blank with a reasonable response. This is particularly curious given that the scientific community has developed a number of helpful scientific tools. When asked if any food contained arsenic, most people gave the wrong response. Most Americans feel a toaster has a better chance of spontaneous combustion than a toaster oven. Lastly, many people do not realize that stem cell research occurs in nonhuman items. Most people associate the study with only research with human subjects.

Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around 2 p.m. Pacific Time, and was cleared for a grand takeoff when the first officer noticed a red light flashing, signaling a problem in the cargo hold.
According to a company statement on Facebook, the captain returned to the gate and secured the plane. This time, the problem was discovered to be an exceptionally sleepy ground maintenance worker who had become trapped inside the cabin cargo hold.
"As we investigated the issue, it was determined that a maintenance worker had become trapped by the air stairs," said Reggie Assaly, Senior Manager for Cargo Outsourcing for Alaska Airlines. "Our employees acted quickly to confirm the situation, assess the risk and evacuate everyone safely."
17 passengers were transported onto separate Alaska flights to help make up for the cancellation of their afternoon flight. No passengers were injured.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season each of the last three years.
Fred Reeder, special agent in charge for the IRS criminal investigations division field office in Atlanta, says that while some of the methods have been around a while—such as phishing emails that appear to come from the IRS—new versions appear on a regular basis that keep cybercriminals at the top of their game.
“Last year, we integrated forensic codes for those phishing emails, and this year, based off that activity that is happening in the field, the IRS expanded that to make it even more difficult for bad guys to break into our systems,” he says of the IRS.
Reeder mentions a recent report, using data supplied through the Security Summit initiative, which outlined some of the scams that are being used.

The Office of Multicultural Affairs facilitates the Navigation mentoring program that pairs students with a faculty or staff member who will serve as their Navigation Partner throughout their journey at the University of Dayton. A Navigation Partner can answer questions of students while they navigate the multitude of services available on our campuses and those available in the community.
Navigation is by appointment only. Please fill out the Navigation Interest Form to be connected with a Navigation Partner. For additional assistance, email .
Navigation partners are faculty and staff members who understand the invaluable resource they are to students. Whether a student needs assistance with class selection, academic advising, assistance with career planning, race relations, or with discovering something new here on campus here to listen; our partners are ready to help.
Navigation partners will be trained before the student is connected with a match. A 30-minute training session with be held at a time convenient to all participants. Trained navigation partners will be available through the organizations they identify after hours. Students will be able to identify their navigation partner each semester during Advent, or after their first semester during Campus Connections/Advocate Training.

On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong views about the need for there to be no physical barriers on the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland and although this was originally a political rather than a practical view, his determination to make this happen could have a serious impact, not for the first time, on decisions made by the European Union.

Friends, we've gathered today to say, Yes! Yes to not just the good things about Memphis, but the BEST things about Memphis. The things that make you the happiest to live here. The best stories from your neighborhood. The more colorful or fanciful but weirdly true things that capture the essence of living here.
From a grassroots perspective, your story matters.
We asked you to send us the stories you love most about Memphis. And here it is! From Tradimore to Gardens to The Heights to all the best places to groove on a Saturday night, none of the most-loved stuff about living in Memphis is left out.
Our 78 categories include The Intimidating Literary Landmark, The Best Garden Center, Clouds Rise from, and Bonfire in Your Front Yard. So many of you told us, It's the way we speak. The burst of heartbreak of an epiphany. The overwhelming sense of friendship here.
We encourage you to come right out and say it if you feel like someone else has already said it.

Welcome to my blog!! Here’s a little bit about me.
I’m a feminist and a Christian social ethicist. I studied at Union Theological Seminary in NY with this amazing woman, Beverly Wildung Harrison (and another feminist, Sheryl Harrison (no relation). Eileen Campbell O Connor (also at Union) is now my partner in The Center for Spiritual and Social Justice. Max Stackhouse (who came to Union with Beverly) is also a co-founder. I’ve been invited to give lecture tours with Max, who is retired now. I’ve taught at Albert Theological Seminary, a small ecumenical Methodist seminary in Ft Worth, Texas. I’m in Sojourners with Jim Wallis. I’ll be telling you more about Sojourners as I write posts.
I’d love to hear from you! Leave a comment if you think you can support spiritual feminist/feminist theological reflection and activism. I’m planning a lot of themed posts, so stay tuned!

Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding computer servers with data forced websites to go down or slowed routers to operate slowly, affected some 10 percent of the computers of five telecommunications companies in Korea.
"The possibility of widespread virus infection is low. Hackers infiltrated the computers… and also stole the database files that store data on customers' user IDs and passwords," said police official Lim Chang-hun.
"Hackers want to use the stolen data to steal money or take over the customers' accounts on the Internet, or blackmail users," he added.
The worm was first detected in the United States around 3:00 pm (0830 GMT) last Thursday, with traffic soaring after 10:00 pm (0200 GMT the next day), said Lim.

The opening of the new Park and Read facility coincides with National Bookstart Week, the annual celebration of children’s books which starts this week running until Saturday 25 August. This means the free-to-use facility will be available to children and families for fun filled interactive activities.
The temporary children’s library has been made possible by Bradford Council, Chief Culture Officer Sonja Hall and crowdfunding donations. It comes after the Council confirmed that it is still hoping to achieve delivery of a purpose-built library and library hub in the heart of Bradford city centre, previously postponed by the emergency plans being put in place in response to the pandemic.
Declared a literary and artistic UNESCO City of Literature in 2009, more than two million books are currently issued each year from Bradford’s reduced number of libraries, against the former globally acclaimed environments such as the former Central Library.

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a siphonic vent stack just west of Buffalo Expressway. Flames burned unchecked for more than five hours, and firefighters were finally able to control the fire during the second night on Sunday night.
The homeless shelter has occupied the former Caruth Haven motel for almost 20 years, according to Marc Metzler, a co-founder of the Bridge, a nonprofit dedicated to eradicating homelessness downtown. The motel was recently renovated based on a plan initiated by Mayor Mike Rawlings. A recent study revealed that homelessness has become a generational cycle, with 12-year-olds from homeless families almost 80 percent more likely were also future victims of homelessness.
Meanwhile, Metro Dallas Homeless Alliance President Erv Hoysted says there are more than 1,500 homeless individuals in the county.

"Hey. Can anyone help me write some things about [The Handmaid's Tale]? I have a vague statement for a personal statement and not much else," C wrote in her tweet.

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 50 percent over the past several months.
Worried that other hazards, like liability, might be hurting business too, Colorado also has passed a law against so-called “dram shop” lawsuits, roughly 175 of which are filed annually by people injured at bars and taverns.
Similar so-called “tort reform” measures limiting damages in lawsuits have been passed by other states, but two lawsuits already have challenged the Colorado statute in specific tavern cases.
The issue is what constitutes public policy where constitutional rights and health are intertwined, not faulty legislation, according to Ross Fraser of the Colorado Trial Lawyers Association.
The voter-approved amendment imposes an absolute ban on smoking in all enclosed work spaces and unventilated outdoor areas, but bars and taverns

Members of Bassa, the British Airways cabin crew section of the Unite union, have voted to be balloted over a new offer from BA management.
The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, on pay, pensions and terms and conditions.
BA cabin crew went on all-out strike for two days in September last year to defend wages, pensions and working conditions; a ballot of cabinet crew members gave 89% for charges and 78% for industrial action.
But since then Gary International Ambulance Services, a revenue stream for the union, has been closed. International Ambulances were vital to raise money for the union to even be considered an ‘acceptable’ negotiator.
On the whole, the new deal is unacceptable, but a number of concessions have been made on working conditions, which might not otherwise have been forthcoming.

Twenty years ago, this same space made one visitor shed tears.
It was 1984, and Greenberg, a past member of SCU’s horticulture department faculty, became emotional—he was thinking about amphibium.
A former science teacher from Richmond, Virginia, Greenberg researched chytrid fungus. The disease has afflicted amphibians in New Guinea for many years.
Amphibians are prized not only for their beauty but as an indicator of the environment’s health, because the frogs’ eggs are ingested by salamanders, newts, salmon, fish, birds, and other animals that then migrate throughout the ecosystem.

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel ERT2 on Friday.
"We are negotiating on the extension of Turkey's Stream (pipeline), which is not mentioned in the (2012) agreement with the EU-European Commission, from the Bulgarian-Turkish border to the neighboring districts of Thrace, with more specific program notes," he said.
The EU decision on the extension of the pipe needs to be approved by the European Commission as a third party. If the EU agrees it will be included in the EU multiannual financial framework for 2021-2027, based on the latest amendments, and the decision regarding extension made by the Greek Council of Ministers becomes null and void, Tsipras said.

The bit from her post on which I’d like to comment and expound is when she discusses the danger that comes from conversing unnecessarily:
“To love another consists in thriving to know him. Each person, no matter how ordinary, stands out from the rest by some point, he has some distinction. Conversing with a person is a grace, if your infinitely deep mind can bestow upon superficial minds and allow them a flash of your brilliance, giving them a foreshadow of themselves. Otherwise love is impossible. Of course, it’s always mutual: The person who knows and loves you best will always be the person you know least. In recent times music has gradually climbed higher on the entertainment ladder. Musicians always receive the applaud leaving the technical producers or sound engineers out. Little does one know or hear about them.
One of such sound engineers, Oscar Samuel has died.
Samuel died at the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital.
Oscar Samuel, a resident soundengineer with Living Faith Senior High School was reportedly murdered in cold blood by suspected armed robbers who came into the school to rob.
It is said that students and teaching staff of the school heard bullets being fired and seized with utmost fear.
Security men later immobilized the armed robbers but not before Samuel and six other people had been killed and many injured including the soundographer and students.
The school now lies in ruin with the bodies of dead students laid in the school sick beds while others have been evacuated to the university of Nigeria teaching hospital for medical attention.
By the time Ogwu Uche (Governor of Anambra) and Asofo Enugu ( state Governor) visited the school, everything lay in sad state.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension on both ends of the runway to double its length to 4,000m, the length of the existing Delta terminal to 900m, and adding 10 more world-class aircraft gates set within glass walls. Six airplane gates on the lower level and four elevated jetway bridges with wide boarding walkways will be added.
"This unprecedented investment in infrastructure … will mean less traffic, cleaner air, and more jobs… for the people of New York," said Governor Andrew Cuomo.
More importantly, It will mean … possibilities for tens of thousands of jobs, for growth in other city industries. It is the chance to build the economy of tomorrow."

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Yamanaka said his family was also subject to a form of racism perpetrated from within their own Japanese community. “(The community) tended to look at us with disfavor or scorn because they felt Japanese families should only marry Japanese and so forth,” he said.
Yamanaka’s parents did eventually permit him to marry a non-Japanese girl, and the couple’s mixed marriage survives to this day.

For more than 56 years, the Boys & Girls Clubs of America have been keeping teens off the streets at a time when three major studies are showing a need.

Armed with their motto, "Great Futures Start Here," more than 10 Boys & Girls Clubs across the metro area give local teens a place outside of school where they can play video and board games, root for their home basketball teams, get a one-on-one career mentor, and participate in academic and career training.
The Club offers classes from health sciences to the arts. Boys & Girls Club officials there have a goal of graduating 500 members in five years.

DLL International started the proceedings against adapting the IT term ‘cloud and seeking £15,000 over ‘passing-off’.
DLL describes itself as “uniquely focused on contention free outdoor Wi-Fi services in Europe, managing more than 10,000 Wi-Fi access points in 109 cities worldwide”.
Cloudnet initially stayed silent on the issue, and even welcomed new sign-ups to its website in May despite colleagues cautioning it would be seen as provocative.

It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But there's a lot of confusion when it comes to determining what FODMAPs are. Let’s dive into what BeyondTheBurn recommends everyone should know about FODMAPS.
FODMAPS, or Fermentable - Oligosaccharides, Disaccharides, Monosaccharides And Polyols, is a collection of short chain carbohydrates that are naturally occurring in vegetables and fruits. When consumed the FODMAPS accumulate in the intestines and are fermented by bacteria resulting in increased biological activity. This increased activity can lead to certain side-effects for some such as bloating, diarrhea, gas, rashes, stomach cramping, and weight change in some people. The effects of FODMAPS are called intestinal FODMAPS disorders because they occur in the gut.

The money was inside a man’s wallet police found on the floor of the Livingston Avenue house in which he was caught. The man’s name was not released.
Police were called to the home at 4:08 p.m. Monday after someone complained of a man banging on the door of the house and when the door was opened, he ran off, said Sgt. Daren Hase of the Youngstown police.
Police said the home is vacant and the man tried to open the kitchen door, which was locked. He then banged on the door, police said.
Officers obtained a description of the man from a witness and located him within minutes walking on Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, which is less than a block away from the house.

NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends with one of the friends ending the relationship for reasons left unsaid. The NFL says it’s a technique that seems to cancel the “gasp” reaction that might come if the incidents of abuse were more in your face.
The league says the goal is for more people to see the video and know that the issue of domestic abuse is universally condemned, whether the abusers wear NFL uniforms or try to blame the victim with the explanation “Boys will be boys.” In an age when reporting of domestic abuse by athletes is common, the league wants to start a conversation about the problem in real life.
Domestic violence has been a hot button issue in pop culture since actress Ray Rice famously knocked his girlfriend unconscious in an elevator after a fight in 2014. In the days after Rice’s video was released, more allegedly violent incidents involving professional athletes began to emerge

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of President Obama’s “full-blown sexual revolution,” Republican appointees on Friday reinstituted the “Global Gag Rule” for global family planning programs under the auspices of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).
Beginning in 1984, Republican president Ronald Reagan made the “Global Gag Rule” an unofficial policy during his first term, withdrawing aid to any country that was receiving national loans from the World Bank or the U.S. Export-Import Bank, if those countries permitted services such as abortion.
Also known as the Mexico City Policy, it was made a formal policy in 1988 by George H.W. Bush and is now going back on an Obama order to end all taxpayer funding of abortions overseas in January 2009.

By Kathie Klarreich Kathie Klarreich, a journalist who lives in Haiti, is cofounder of Caribbean Exchange, a San Francisco-based education and action group.
HAITIAN President General Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier has begun to take the political prisoners from Haitian jails and let them out, but economic prisoners remain trapped. On Bosquet Street in Port-au-Prince, Haiti's postwar capital, men lie on their backs in the sweltering heat, stretched out under an homemade bar. Most are locked in stocks, and behind them stand large metal bars on which their wrists and ankles are locked by handcuffs. The men were protesting the food price hikes that will make the rations consumed at the jail in Port-au-Prince, where they've been locked up since 1982, even more meager than before. Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by lost trails, Native American legends, or Europeans just stepping out of their front window. Solitude had an appeal at this time in history, but space across the vast American land was too quickly dissipated. The territory that had at the turn of the century seemed so vast now seems almost cramped by cities, roads, and towns. As Miles Glavin has reassembled in By measured distances, scenes of early Americana:

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their surroundings and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible there unsustainable. While the effect of that explosion on our own corner of the galaxy might be ultimately inconsequential, the Earth's location within our corner of the Milky Way does, according to one space-based instrument, indicate that the Sun's home region may be nearing one of its periodic supernova events.
Located within our home galaxy, solar flares produce intermittent bursts of bright radiation that, in turn, send off wavy ripples and energetic energetic plasmas away from the Sun toward the Earth and beyond.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding efforts underway following a phenomena that swept through much of Melanesia.
While the world watched the Olympic action taking place in Rio de Janiero, the cyclone that swept through the islands of Vanuatu and caused frightening images of death and destruction missed more than 250,000 people.
Weighlifting super heavyweight, David Noba (77 kilogram) - whose family home had been destroyed by tropical cyclone Pam - took to the stage in the competition having lost in his first round bout.
Not realising the cameras were rolling, Noba left the stage and ran through to the back of the stadium to an area that had been set up to showcase the work done to aid reconstruction in Vanuatu.
"The sport is something that kept me focused while we were cleaning up," he said.

Image caption Lemn Sissay says he wants to show young people who have left care they are wanted by society and are "worth something"
Young people who have spent part of their childhood in care have been invited to special events to mark National Care Leavers' Week.
They were launched by poet and children's author Lemn Sissay, who is a care leaver himself.
Care Leavers UK, a grassroots organisation, holds events all over the UK - this year's theme is Identity Matters.
The charity says care leavers can face discrimination, lower pay and higher poverty rates.
Lemn Sissay, who lives in Manchester and is from Wolverhampton, said: "Imagine having drawn your first breath as a tiny human into a care system where nobody tells you that you're wanted.
"Imagine not being told that you're wanted by anybody, that you're wanted by your family, the society which you're living in, or your adoptive town."

Tim Russert discusses his childhood, faith, the catholic church, religion mixing with politics, and a life of service with On Faith's Sally Quinn.
Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political journalism and then shocked us with his sudden passing away Friday, was a devout Catholic as children of his parents' generation often are. His father, an investment-banking lawyer, had come from Italian stock and was a registered Democrat, but raised his son, who was born into a professional family in Lincoln, Neb., in the predominantly Republican culture of the Midwest in the 1950s.
The boy, Timothy James Russert Jr., became a product of his Midwestern roots -- and, for a few years, also had the chance to absorb the more cosmopolitan sensibilities of Rome.
Tim's Catholic faith was central to his life and career. He often spoke of it in the years when he was close to his audience -- in his speeches at both political party conventions in 2004, for instance -- but generally kept it private, even with those he worked most closely with

LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone "beyond privacy grounds".
LinkedIn has now said it plans to test an alternative "contextual" advertising model.
"Target increases the opportunity for advertisers to appear on relevant content," LinkedIn said in a statement.
It added it had asked members for their permission to use their details.
Some 15 million members are already signed up to the service, which lets them publish profiles, stay tuned into their networks and access free training tools.
The service is popular with people who are looking for new jobs, staff and sales leads, as the network acts as a recommendation tool.
The firm says it is constantly improving its privacy options and says it currently notifies users who appear in adverts and have the option to opt-out of future ads.
Source: BBC | Tue, 21 Nov 2006 20:02:50 | By BBC News Online'

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“Concussion” means that a “child has been hit in the head or a blow to the body that was high enough to cause the head and brain to move rapidly back and forth,” the CDC said.
The agency said that every school should have a written concussion plan specifically designed for children, sufficient staff to treat concussions onsite and athletic trainers.
In a list of recommendations, the CDC urged schools to take steps to prevent concussions, both recognizing and treating them, which includes a program for actions by officials, coaches or parents to remove a child from the athletic event until the child feels better. The child should be evaluated by a health care provider. The health care worker in turn should give treatment guidelines and return to play instructions to the child and the school.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to distributed mountaintop or rural locations to improve resilience during winter weather. They expect to produce a prototype within one year with the help of venture funding.
Compared to other processes that generate power from precipitation, this entirely passive device is low-maintenance, self-powered, lightweight and cost-effective. Other techniques to harvest energy from snow potential in turnover or other mechanical motions involve bulky equipment and specialized knowledge about a structure’s energy consumption needs and circulation. This is an equally low-maintenance option that is reductionist, easily adaptable to different surfaces, and does not need batteries or other high-tech components.
Eric Freyer, assistant professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering at the UCLA Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science, led the project, which appears in the journal Scientific Reports.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video to explain his philosophy.
That selflessness was borne out of experimentation. For years, Smith has been conducting an academic equivalent of the scientific method: Plan, do, and then review what he's learned from the experience. "I've always done things the hard way," he explains. His 15 years in online media honed his curiosity for new technologies and social media networks.
He was itching for a new challenge and tried to imagine what that might look like. An analytical thinker like Smith came away from the experiment with one idea: Freemium.
Enabled by the explosive rise of free social networking sites, he was confident freemium service providers had an opportunity to leverage these new bountiful tools without serious financial risk.
"Nothing kills creativity faster than accountants," Smith says.

When Rick Gates turned against his former boss, he described a parallel ethical universe where lying and cheating were as comfortable as a well-tailored ostrich suit.
You know what would be surprising? If Rick Gates had told the truth.
His appearance at Trump Tower was no surprise. After all, it’s part of the deal personally negotiated by the elfish Don McGahn, who as White House counsel protected the president from self-incrimination.
The president’s lawyers had to do better than Michael Cohen doing what he does best. They had to either (a) take the easy way out (by sending a lot of money to a porn star) or (b) lose their preferred residency in Miami.
Immigrate to the motherland. Pretend to be legit. Avoid charges.
This deal would seemingly be an unfair trade, except for the fact that the two wars in Iraq, recklessly launched by the young man traveling with the president, cost at least $2 trillion.

Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Ralf Kudryavzev of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow, have succeeded for the first time in studying a family of extragalactic radio sources at the highest possible wavelength. The team combined measurements made with the lighter and more compact planetary lidar system CLASSI at the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT), at the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory on the island of La Palma, Spain, with observations from the kilometer-wavelengths radio telescopes.
For astronomers, this dataset provides us with an unbiased view of these sources that covers all wavelengths in a single visit to the telescope. Such a comprehensive dataset will become available again in a few years, thanks to the ESO’s future extrasolar planet search facility, the European Extremely Large Telescope (E-ELT, 38 meters). America's political history has been written in the fierce narrative of war -- not only our country's many military clashes with foreign nations, but also our own unending war for democracy in the U.S.
This isn't easy to admit. The American "love of country"—real or feigned—is too sacred for me ever to deny.
At the same time, the intense glorification and deification of our military puts a crushing yoke around its soldiers and the politics it supports. That by itself would be bad enough. But a military that has absorbed mid-twentieth century developments in warfare that make the acquisition of weapons more efficient more singularly than a quest for peace, makes this a lofty ordeal that threatens us as much as it protects our wellbeing.
So we must face the question, does our military contribute to the defense of American freedom, or is it a major cause of our lack of it?
A nifty quarter million American troops serve this country as its minority of path-pavers who exemplify our great nation's courageous experiment in republican principles.

ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
Temperatures reach 1,500C and one-square-metre surface flashes with a billion photons for 100 meters.
Amateur astronomer David King predicts it produces five or 10 meteors an hour – but last night's Perseid event saw up to 100 meteors per hour, and left much of the world's population on its feet.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include a longer, more explanatory comment about the original tweet. But there’s a big, crucial limitation: users who want to retweet with comment have to reply to their own tweet, meaning that the message essentially generically targets everyone on their Twitter timeline.
Users such as Politwoops and Milo Yiannopolous, who often use their Twitter accounts as megaphones for their brands, have found it relatively easy to use “reply to own tweet” for their promotional tweets.
In the Politwoops example below, Politico used “reply to own tweet” to promote an in-house podcast on the horrific sexual assault allegations against portions of Bernie Sanders’s campaign staff. Trade turnover between Russia and its second largest trade partner, Germany, increased 8.4 percent and reached nearly €62 billion ($70 billion) in 2018 compared to previous year, according to the German trade lobby. This was Germany’s biggest export success this year, Russian Federal Customs Office reported.
In 2018, the total trade turnover between Russia and Germany increased by 12.2 percent compared to 2017. The number of direct industrial projects implemented together with partners from Germany increased by 150 percent compared to 2017 results.
Deputy Director General of Vnesheconombank (VEB), Evgeniy Sukhov, stated that non-resource based exports from Germany to Russia grew by 62 percent, compared to Germany foreign trade with Russia overall. Highest growth was recorded in imports from Germany of furniture (+41.4 percent).

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable number. Its small-schools reform project follows the lead of many other districts across the country. The San Antonio Independent School District (SAISD) has been working on school turnaround for more than a decade, spending tens of millions of dollars implementing everything from long school days with longer years to emulating iSSyI schools in Boston. But in 2007 the district set a new goal: by 2012, fix or close 22 low performing schools. These weren’t new, lower performing campuses, but established neighborhood schools with long histories and deep ties to their communities. The district asked the campuses to do three things. First, they asked the schools to adopt a more culturally relevant curriculum that would better prepare every student for college and work. Second, they asked the schools to increase parent engagement and student attendance. Third, they asked the schools to narrow achievement

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct - "leftists, communists and progressive people" - had been "fabricated", the Times reported. The National Association of Judges added the persecution was made possible through complicity from their fellow judges and accused many of the injustices of the military regime, which was installed under General Augusto Pinochet.
Previously, judges had expressed regret that the trials of military dictatorship abuses did not always go according to the rule of law but said they had no official complaint against their colleagues.
'The whole truth'
"Many times in their defence of internal order, judges acted through institutional complicity of guilt. These actions contributed to the violation of the rights of citizens... the whole truth has never come out in our country," the statement went on.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Nashville after undergoing surgery for a fall. He was 71.
Reed, who was made an official Nashville resident in 1981 at the request of the mayor, wrote and performed the theme to the Clint Eastwood movie, "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." Reed also appeared in several Eastwood films and was the genre’s most successful cross-over artist during the peak of his 1970s recording career.
In 1970, he conquered a different field, that of drag racing and won three national championships in the Southern Drag Racing Association. Later that year, he sold everything he owned and pawned his championship rings to finance his music career in Nashville.

Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of bloodshed generation after generation.
In the southern city of Bengkulu, across the Strait of Malacca from Sumatra island, stacks of last year's seeds line a tin-roofed pulpita in front of the house of commemorations.
Driven by a fervour of justice,Footnote 2 the area's people, descendants of the original inhabitants and slaves from Africa, strike the structure daily with kris, the ubiquitous short, roughly curved sword sharpened on both sides of its blade.
They believe the force of their blows propels the evil spirits resting in the metal. They take comfort in reciting Muslim prayers over the frightening and grim remnants of the Indonesian military's territorial conquests.

Beantown Bedding cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple.
College students can find time for all sorts of activities, but one chore that always seems to drop off the bottom of their to-do list is laundry.
Washing and drying one's clothes could literally take days – and cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple get this. Their Boston-based startup, Beantown Bedding, is a subscription service that helps shorten that to-do list.
Rather than having all that time to laundry clothes in a dorm room or while studying abroad, Beantown Bedding provides a once-a-week pickup, including a laundry card that students use to keep track of what gets picked up. (Washing machine instructions are also available.) After submission, students can pick up their clean clothes on the way home or three days later.

The longtime top sportswriter at ESPN says he borrowed one of his best spurts of prose from Yogi Berra for the preface to his latest book about how President Donald Trump cheats at golf, and the publisher made him take out the quote.

It’s already been a busy year for the Female Founders Alliance.
The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so.
The first of four quarterly targeted sessions aimed at women-owned businesses launched in April, the “Boot Camp” webinar series—taught by marketing, sales and finance mentors—provides an opportunity to learn best practices from successful female entrepreneurs. It has pulled more than 2,200 attendees, roughly one in five of them international.

As Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff took to the stage, he explained that Einstein is designed with three goals in mind: knowledge from each customer's data, recommendation for "what intelligent actions" to take, and "the ability to learn and get smarter."
Sounds familiar, no? That's because this is Salesforce's answer to Amazon.com's AWS, Microsoft's Azure, Google's Cloud Machine Learning Update, and Oracle's SkyDNS, each one with its very own silly sounding name for "intelligent" platform powers.

Russell Westbrook was long gone before the final horn sounded on Tuesday night.
So was one of the longest running basketball debates in this city.
Both were chased off by Damian Lillard and CJ McCollum, two rookie guards who have replaced the Thunder tandem as the most energetic and tough young players on the court.
They are the faces of a franchise that has grown up and into a legitimate contender, ready to make their move on the NBA while Oklahoma City works through some growing pains in its own development.
Lillard used a jumper with less than a minute left while McCollum knocked down four free throws in the final 17 seconds, scoring 25 and 23 points, respectively.
Westbrook scored 38 and 29 points in his final two regular-season games with the Thunder.
Just to sum up the difference in this game from those two years ago:
So long Westbrook.
McCollum is just the kind of big-time player Portland's Damian Lillard needs to emerge.

LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as authorities try to contain a surge in malaria deaths.
Malaria is one of Africa’s largest killers, claiming the lives of around 630,000 people each year, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa, according to the World Health Organization(WHO).
In addition to Ridge SA90, the world’s first anti-mosquito wall coating, company step-up to Japan’s leading paint and coatings firm is also working with Japanese NGO’s and other providers of donated mosquito nets to select families in need, and to help children receive the best possible education.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to accept fixed prices set by the government.
Tanzania is one of the world’s top exporters of unshelled cashews and its farmers have struggled to get the best prices in the past, adding domestic pressure to government planters.
They had been pushing authorities to set a wholesale floor price of 2,000 Tanzanian shillings ($1) a kilo.
In an attempt to control speculation in the market, Tanzania’s Ministry of Agriculture announced last week it would buy 100,000 metric tonnes at an official price of 2,000 shillings (62 U.S. cents) a kilo.

Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach includes more than 250 million users. The deal also merges Verizon’s Go90 mobile video business, which has struggled, with AOL’s Millennial-focused appeal.
The deal took five years to conclude. The companies confirmed they reached a definitive agreement on Sunday, after weeks of talks.
The deal valued AOL at $50 per share, or about $4.4 billion. The purchase price represents a 35 percent premium over AOL’s closing stock price on August 7.
For many, it brings together AOL’s legacy roots with Verizon’s stretch into mobile. Verizon Communications CEO Lowell McAdam said that for customers, who are “always on, always connected, it’s about the same thing — ready when they are.”

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 5th Marines — left the Marjah District on June 21. While less than 2,000 Marines remain in Afghanistan, they still must bolster nearby Somali and smaller contingents in Sangin, Shakooray, Washir, Maywand and Musa Qala districts — all of which are in Helmand.
Most of the Marines coming to Helmand will replace soldiers in Southeastern Regional Command, Helmand’s neighbor to the Southwest. They are not expected to leave Helmand as long as possible will not have a significant impact on the region’s operations.
Elements of 3rd Bn, 5th Marines, will split up in order to take existing patrol bases in Helmand province with only one marine listening post left in Afghanistan’s central province from what started as two.

WASHINGTON - As the threat of internal corruption dogs the ranks of border security forces, the Obama administration is considering regularly rotating agents to other locations to distance them from the persuasive power and money of Mexico's drug cartels.
As the threat of internal corruption dogs the ranks of border security forces throughout the United States, the Obama administration is contemplating deploying lower-level agents to Mexico and elsewhere to temporarily preserve their objectivity.
The idea of trans-border assignments for agents and other low-ranking officers — known as lateral moves, like those made by operations analysts and civil engineers in the military -- was among the recommendations made last week by a task force charged with working out the troubles facing the U.S. Border Patrol.

Bing documents their factors for determining content quality; Bing's version of Google Panda?
Michael Basilyan, Senior Program Manager from the Bing Content Quality Team, shared a nice set of details on the Bing blog this week about the content quality factors considered in their web search algorithm.
They focus on two main criteria: E-A-T (establishment authority, expertise & trustworthiness), and content originality. Specifically, the factors they consider, in order of importance, are:
Authority or expertise and trustworthiness (this comes before content originality)
Website / Domain Authority (competitive)
Author protocol (with "official" sites having more
weight)
Author location (with "accredited" sites having more weight)
Author recognition and regulation (if the site is in government run site)
Expert identity (with "disqualifying" factors being specified)
Abstract labels tags
Spammy or poor quality links
Hidden paragraphs and content
Unintelligible or experimental content

The first time the bagel franchise thought about relocating was in 2001 when the current East Main Street shop was converted from Jewel’s Shoe Repair Shop to a retail space.
“It evolved with business and things kept going,” owner Bob Goldberg said.
Mr. Goldberg was present on Saturday for the grand opening while employees handed out complimentary brownies to customers who wanted to share in the occasion, hoping to build buzz for the chain’s future renovation in the years to come.

Will the GDPR affect your business?
Story From LBMC: GDPR compliance: Will the EU’s new data regulation affect your business?
Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data protection regulator, the GDPR will require more clarity in data-related contracts, increased control of the use of personal data and higher security for data used in cloud applications. Whether your business is located in the EU or not, the GDPR will have international impact. You need to know what it takes to comply, and how those steps will affect your typical business operations.
Established to spell out specific and binding requirements for handling EU citizens’ data, and create unambiguous guidelines, the regulation has far-reaching implications worldwide. The GDPR indicates that regulated firms must:
Notify users if there’s been a data breach that may affect them
Gain “explicit

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. (CBSNewYork) — Police in Westchester County were searching Monday for the person who has been sending disturbing mail to several women in Dobbs Ferry.
As CBS 2’s Marcia Kramer reported, investigators said a postcard that read “those shoes would look good on your feet” was sent out on Oct. 20.
One day later, Kramer reported, a picture of a woman was slipped into mail that also read “those pants would look good on your ass.”
The victim’s name was not released and cops did not reveal the identity of the women whose mail was sent.
“It’s a frightening event,” said Dobbs Ferry police commissioner John McKenna. “Every time there is something in the mail we send the people that work at that house an alert that we received an inappropriate volume of mail.”
Police said they know the post office and concerned citizens will be alert for the next suspicious mailing.

Like a horror-film villain, “pink slime”—the cheeky nickname for scraps of slaughtered cow that have been pulverized, defatted, subjected to ammonia steam to kill pathogens, then “reformed” under pressure with beet-juice filler and L-cysteine, an amino acid —has been killing the livestock industry.
More pink slime is classified as “meat product” under federal law than any other food other than mushrooms, although it isn’t used in the production of mushrooms.
The Republic of Ireland banned it in 2000. Chile has just banned it. The Netherlands and Poland have recently outlawed it. The public relations nightmare from Down Under in 2002 has been notable, particularly as America’s leaders have long been fans. It was served to food processors in Melbourne at a 2011 networking event hosted by Yum! Brands! Sizzler and Subway.

CHATHAM — Glenwood High School’s principal has given notice that he will resign June 30 after one year on the job.
Russell Tepen, 50, whose resignation was approved Thursday night by the Caddo Parish Board of School Zoning Delegeates, is the latest Glenwood administrator to leave in about 15 months.
Glenwood is scheduled to be consolidated with Benton High School in August, but parents have said they consider Tepen a better leader than BHS principal Tom Palmer. Nine of 15 Glenwood and Benton principals, a special education director, a business manager and a school nurse have left the It’s also the only school where community leaders are so opposed the consolidation that they have filed court papers seeking an injunction that would block the merger.
Tepen’s resignation letter, which was approved Thursday, offered no specific reason for it. “I would like to inform you of my plans to resign from my position as principal of Glenwood High School, effective at the close of business on June 30, 2007."

All Master students in Teaching and Curriculum (with the only exception of those working towards their first initial teaching certification, who instead complete a Comprehensive Portfolio) need to complete a Master's Essay as the end result of their studies. Undergraduate students must enroll into three credits (CMSC-597) to complete their Essay. The Master's Essay program provides an opportunity for students to produce a written work of original scholarship in the field of teacher education. Topics selected by the students must fall within the field of educational theory and pedagogy, which is discussed at length in the course. When preparing for their Essays, students undertake a critical investigation of the literature in a particular educational topic of interest, analyze specific pedagogical examples, and propose new scholarship of practical value to professional practice. At the completion of their Essays, students will defend their paper at a formal oral presentation ("defense,") for a committee of two faculty members and all M.Ed. students.

Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — 320 people — to its knees in seconds. The latest death toll is 31 with another 12 people unaccounted for.
When it was over, Vernazza — a village of bougainvillea-clad buildings that beckons visitors with views of its cobalt waters — looked like a childish drawing of a city gone mad, snarled, shredded by its chaotic relationship with mother nature, writes Jim Rankin, a photographer for the Toronto Star. Thousands of grey and brown rocks like a shattered mess. Metal roofs lopped off. Cars submerged. A church wedding turned to hell.
People gathered on the patio of a restaurant to learn a grim truth.
And by newsstands of the city center, tragedy was on sale.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des ducs de Bretagne. This impressive building was constructed along the Loire River in the early 15th century as a ducal residence and then carried on by multiple generations. Today, you’ll find the restored chateau filled with period furnishings, portraits, and tapestries while the eight rooms of the Town Hall of Nantes showcase the history of the town. For an entertaining overview of this city’s past and present, check out Phare de Roche Rio (Fire Museum of Nantes). The site of a lighthouse from 1739, this two-story building was first damaged during the French Revolution in 1794 and then once again during the Second World War a century later. Tour the expositions, then climb its 78 steps and take in the prime view at the Top of the Rock. Next

COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) - Northwestern and Maryland have followed similar paths to this point in the football season.
Where they go from here could well be determined by the result of their first-ever meeting.
The Wildcats (8-1) take on No. 25 Maryland (9-1) in Tuesday night's Military Bowl. The game kicks off a day earlier than usual to avoid traffic during the running of the Maryland Football Bowl Classic in downtown Baltimore.
For Northwestern and Maryland, it's a defining moment in each of their seasons.
No team has more to gain by winning the postseason game than Northwestern, which at this point would have a chance to snag a berth in the BCS. The Wildcats, one of five teams ranked behind No. 2 Ohio State in the poll used for the BCS standings, would become a Big Ten title contender with a win over the Terps.
The team would also be the Big Ten's representative in the Rose Bowl if there was an unprecedented five Big Ten teams in the final BCS rankings.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of its raw water supply.
As a result, the utility is returning its scheduled raw water source from the Ohio River to the Owensboro Regional and Electric Power Broker Water Theory.
According to a spokeswoman for the utility, they will be using improved raw water quality reverse osmosis method, which should eliminate hydrogen sulfide, along with other contaminants from entering the drinking water.
Once they determine the improvement of water quality, the utility will begin issuing boil orders for its customers.
To ensure customers are notified about any boil orders, the utility will notify customers via voice message, Facebook and by text messaging for the upcoming boil advisory.
Customers who are not subscribed to these services can find documents and details posted on their website.
All boil advisories will also be posted on their website and social media.
For more information on its website, visit illinois

"The kids walked to Wheatley, and I wanted to be as close to my kids and their parents as possible, where I could be part of the community," Hamilton said.

Two sets of developers are merging their software to provide application suites that enable companies to gain better visibility into the supply chains. One team will use supply chain risk management capabilities, the other will create business performance monitoring software.
London-based Qiva Inc. has developed an automated trading system that connects to a supply chain management application such as SAP AG's ERP software, allowing software providers to automate financial transactions between businesses. Annapolis, Md.-based services provider Vigilance Inc., meanwhile, developed a five-in-one business performance suite that comprises six modules--finance, reporting, personnel, takeover/change management, process mapping and computer needs assessment--all designed to change the way organizations measure and analyze the value of information.

Fredericka Wagner has pleaded not guilty to three charges of aggravated murder in a death penalty case that includes five adults and three children. Wagner says she is innocent, and she won't say how they were killed.

SNC-Lavalin Group Inc., one of Canada's largest engineering firms, is cutting about 1,100 jobs and closing divisions in the downturn around the global economy.
The cuts, which includes about 700 workers in Canada, will deepen those recently announced by B.C.-based Army.com and are part of the Montreal-based company's plans to slash global expenses by $40-million this year.
The planned reductions also include closing quieter divisions of the firm, which built part of the new United Nations headquarters in New York, including a U.S. division focused on transportation.

After a deliberate shift in police training, excessive force complaints against the Dallas Police Department dropped by 64% between 2009 and 2014. The number of arrests and officer-involved shootings continued to decline following the city's reform of officer community and de-escalation training. Medina (2015) sets out to determine if a direct correlation exists between community-based de-escalation training and declines in police use-of-force complaints and finds that the effect is undeniable. The breach may have compromised employee personal information in less than 1 percent of email inboxes.
The State Department detected unusual activity in its unclassified email system that may have compromised some employees’ personal information, a department spokesman said Friday.
Earlier in January, the agency reportedly suspended access to the unclassified email system used by its secretary, career staff and special envoys. The department has been using this in place of the Global Mail System, which is considered so insecure that it is phasing it out. Now, over 97 percent of all email traffic is processed through the new 21st Century platform and around 3 percent of the workforce is scheduled to be moved to it.
The unusual activity detected on Jan. 5 may have resulted in unauthorized access to the department’s Exchange relays. For starters, the company is changing its app policy to accommodate games by outsiders that target teenagers, and instead open the door to games by developers that reach younger users. This comes on the heels of a recent Facebook update that included loopholes for such apps, thanks to pressure from outside developers.

If developers have to pay their own payment providers -- or use existing Facebook apps -- the quality of games and apps could slump.
